reviewText:
This is among the few simulator games such as Euro Truck Simulator and farming simulator that actually does a good job. Game runs smoothly, has minimal bugs, well designed and is fun.

Pros:
+Manage your own car garage
+Nice textures and models
+Test driving
+Garage customization
+Minimal bugs and glitches
+Runs at 60 fps
+Developers are actively working on improving and adding features to game

Neutral:
~Needs more cars (coming soon in dlc)
~Would like to see more cables and parts under engine hood (bit empty atm)
~Different engine types would be interesting (diesel, hybrid, older style engines, vans)

Cons:
(Remember the developers are actively working on this game)

-Career mode could use a few more features (ranking, economy, business decisions)
-Some UI improvements can be made (selling and buying multiple parts in tedious)
-Main car parts are in cars however fuel lines, brake lines, radiator pipes, electrical cables etc are absent

reviewText: I come from Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 and found that it (CM Sim 2014) was enjoyable but once I beat the game for the first time and played some of the DLC I felt like I didn't have a reason to pick the game up. When I heard about Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 being in crowdfund mode I was hesitant to put more money down as I felt like it'd be the same thing. A decent time waster until you beat the game. After looking at what they had so far I started to get excited for the title and immediately pledged enough to get the game when it was released. I received my code earlier today and began playing it.\n\nThe menu is completely different and I found it to be fluid and well designed. It immediately gave me a good vibe. I quickly and eagerly created a profile and began playing. As soon as I started working on the car I automatically fell in love with how it felt. In the previous title it felt like the menus were slow and sluggish. It felt like a burden just to check my inventory. In CMS 2015, that's not the case. The keys are simple and understandable yet pay homage to the original title. Taking off and putting parts on was a breeze. I found myself immerse and even at times swearing like I was working on a real car. Not even kidding. At one point when it told me I had to replace a Piston I was like Man forget this game!" yet I quickly dove into the top end and just started taring down and enjoying it. It's immersive and easy at the same time. I played for 4 hours before I could even test drive a car

reviewText:
I own an American muscle car custom garage... so the content in this game is something I'm familiar with.  I'll say that, yes this is a game... and a good one.  But, it is a casual sim and not so much like a Falcon flightsim.  For example, changing the brakes on a car is one thing, but in this game you don't have to spend time bleeding brake lines or... running brake lines or electrical lines.

In real life, gremlins in the electrical systems (wiring harness, fuses, etc) are what takes up so much of my time.  In this game... they're not even there... really (unless you count ignition wiring).  That could be a blessing or a curse because I hate testing 2 miles of insulated copper wire with a multimeter just to figure out why a car has a mysterious parasitic power drain.  In this game... you're either blessed to not have that tedium or let down without having that real sim experience.

Overall, it is a fun GAME.  Little to no bugs.  I only wish the market allowed me to reference my parts list from the build order so I didn't have to go run under the car every time I forgot what suspension part I needed.

Overall, I rate it an 8/10

reviewText:
A view from one who both enjoys driving and also swings spanners for a living.

TLDR version - A very basic introduction into light vehicle components that feels like it needed another 3 months before release. CMS 2014 is more realistic in many ways - sideways evolution not revolution.


Graphics are decent, sounds are reasonably realistic if simple. Music is passable for the first half hour, then gets turned off. An ingame jukebox with your own mp3 folder linked would be great.

Into the reason why we play games - gameplay. The main suspension types (live axle and independant) are well represented along with engine choices. What is lacking is any customisation. Once you've put together 20 or so cars the excitement fails and you feel like you're grinding toward a goal you can't see. You cannot change parts from one car to another to improve horsepower or weight like Redline Racer 2 or similar (incidently a very good car modification game but very buggy).

In my case, I was grinding for 9k experience, the point in which you can buy parling spaces to get cars from the auctions.
I hit 9k, spent my 50g then went shopping at the auctions. Bought an absolute beater for far more then it was worth and took it home. Stripped, rebuilt every component I could, replaced everything else and then looked for a place to market my rebuilt ride.

That's strange, I have no auction option...that's right. You can only sell the cars you buy for a set sum dependant on condition and model, not feed it back to the auction where you bought it. You get paid a minor 'restoration bonus' and actually end up almost even steven from where you started, which considering you've just spent the better part of 30-45mins rebuilding this thing is.....disappointing to say the least.

This seems to underutilise the potentially exciting platform of the auction. Why couldn't we walk the lot before the auction, checking out the cars beforehand or even meet other bidders?
Also on bidding, it seems a very simple but random process - you're not sure why one model car sells for more then the same model in similar condition because you're literally given no information on each unit. Zero. Can't even pan around to see how many panels are missing.

Another lost oppurtunity is the test track - this could have been much larger and give the player a challenge or at least a reason not to on-sell a car but alas no.

Mods are enabled so the community will probably come to the rescue but they shouldn't have to. The pan speed is excellent however not being able to do anything while draining oil or lowering/raising a car on the hoist is immensely frustrating, can't even check the job sheet.

This game is worth money. How much though? To someone like me who already has a sound knowledge base on car mechanics, maybe $5-10. The content there is well done with no bugs I can see which is a pat on the back. I understand it uses DLC and I've bought a couple already, but misses clear oppurtunities to shine using platforms already existing in the game and offers little direction or encouragement to continue either doing customer jobs or rebuilding auction cars. You will get bored at less then 20 hours.

If you want a better understanding of cars, this is a good start at least in names of components and different types of suspension. Some little AVIs on how the different suspensions compare to one another in practise would be great to better educate those who wish to play this game as a learning tool.

A good crack at a title, but over far too quickly with little replay value.


EDIT   -    After playing the 2014 complete version I must say there appears to be more tangible goals at least on the Tuning and 4WD addons, in addition to 2014 having more realistic graphics and engine components (actually has intake from filter housings to throttle bodies unlike 2015). Unfortunately 2014 has slow component removal speed and slow mouse speed and still has limited content..
The best CMS would be an amalgam of the best attributes of both with casual/hardcore mods with more complex components and tuning/mix match options

reviewText: I would really recommend Car Mechanic Simulator for everyone who is interested in cars and how they work. If you have the previous version of this game (Car Mechanic Simulator 2014) and you like it, I still recommend buying the new version since there is a significant update over last version: cars now have much more parts, engines and car bodies can be disassembled and repaired. Now in later stages of game you can buy cars, repair them and sell for profit. The game today also got a FREE content update in form of a new car to repair, the developers said there will be more free content updates. I as a car fan find this game really enjoyable and recommend this to everyone who is interested in cars.

reviewText:
tl;dr pros & cons list:

I recommend you buy this game if you love cars, or want to learn more about cars!

Pros:Awesome leap in graphics, game function, and quality from its sequel
Easy learning curve, it guides you through what to do
A good educational game for learning car parts
It's a learning experience for newbies to cars in general, like myself
A fantastic developer that keeps up with its community
New content and updates are still coming out since it's a relatively new game
There's a large variety of vehicles with several different engines and/or arrangements, but variety isn't introduced much until you get more XP which makes sense
I'm going to list a lot of cons to balance with the pros, but don't misinterpret it, it's a fantastic game.

Cons:Dubstep music on the radio, can easily be turned off however
The game holds your hand almost too much once you become proficient and want a challenge, since it doesn't let you mess up assembling the vehicle
There's no tutorial about how to play the game really, but it always shows you the controls and is really easy to figure out for the most part
It isn't a challenge if you're a mechanic, surprise surprise
It doesn't show you how the parts actually work in the vehicle, if you're looking to learn about that

Now for the non-tl;dr review:
It's an incredible leap in quality from Car Mechanic Simulator 2014, and I'm pleased to say it's a full fledged sequel! Everything is vastly improved, especially the graphics and game mechanics (pun intended). They've also added the ability to buy auctioned vehicles, allowing you to fix them and sell them for profit, among some other big new things. The developers are actively updating the game and listen to the requests of its fanbase which is always a great thing to see. I love a dedicated developer that keeps up to speed with its community. Also, there's a growing multitude of cars available to work on, engines have variation most of the time, and while the game has no tutorial, the learning curve is easy to get over once you figure the parts of a car out. It gives you a very easy start, then slowly gets more and more intricate as you become more proficient in your tasks. It actually gets pretty challenging sometimes.

A lot of people wonder about how realistic it is, so I will go over that in the next paragraph:
I'm no mechanic, so I have no real-life depiction of how realistic the game actually is, but I got an opinion from a friend of mine who really is a mechanic.

The original Car Mechanic Simulator is what initially sparked my interest in how cars work, and now this sequel helps me expand on that. Hell, it got me so intrigued I went out to my car to see if I could take the air filter out! I even watched some YouTube videos on mechanics principles. I really didn't care for cars prior. In fact I knew nothing of cars. Thank this game for inspiring my love in vehicles! After talking to a mechanic friend, he does say the game lacks realistic difficulty because in reality, knowing which tools to use and finding out what is broken is only half the battle, and it holds your hand through putting things back together, as well as taking things apart in the right order. In real life, it's far more possible to forget to put something in the car, or to lose a bolt inside the engine which apparently sounds painful to a mechanic. He said you can't simply pull out some parts like the game does, too, such as a gearbox. Also, the engines it has you work on aren't as wildly varying as real life cars. My car engine has many of the parts the game has, and thanks to the game I could identify a few of the things which felt very satisfying since I had literally no knowledge of it prior. Everything was arranged differently than in the game, though. It's possibly true that the game isn't quite spot-on realistic, however there's nothing I know of that's better at teaching you the parts of a car and how cars work. With the incredible leap in game quality in just one year, I wouldn't be surprised if it'll be marginally closer to real life in the next sequel. I'm not IGN and I give this a 10/10, so that should say something! It was well worth the 16 dollars I spent, as you can't put a price on education and inspiration.

reviewText:
If you like cars and working on them, this game is crazy addictive. Very well done. However, some quality of life improvements need implemented.

-Load times are atrocious. On a modern machine, simply ridiculous in length. This needs adressed.

-The newest DLC is excellent, however, the 1/4 mile needs an option to toggle between manual or automatic, or even a launch control(I realize the older cars don't have this). If you are simply keyboarding, launching a 600+HP vehicle is a terrible chore of finesse. 1/4 mile times will even drop(versus stock, slightly tuned, max tune) until you can find that sweet spot of gear manipulation just to end tire spin. Even then, times are foolishly off what they should be.

-No option to toggle KPH to MPH. Small complaint, but important.

-When tearing a car down, a lot of the screen is wasted space. They need to implement a menu of items and % you already have in your inventory for each part removed. Maybe something as simple as a top 3 % listing to cut down on menu swapping time. This would fit nicely into some of the empty voids on screen. Whether it shows on part removal or part replacement mode. It would improve gameplay ten folds...

-Repairing items at a 90% cap is nice, but when an item is above a certain percentage, say 90-99%, breaking it shouldn't be so simple. Sometimes randomness can cause 100% of these items to break for a LONG stretch. Not a huge deal, but could be improved. Again not huge, but can be very annoying.

-New DLC issue, Superchargers/intake can block distributor cap clip on the back side. Real pain even zoomed in to remove or replace.

-Load times.

-More variety would make it more consuming. Parking lot for customers cars waiting to be fixed(similar to a real shop). More bays. Perhaps even a staff at a certain XP level to allow more projects with less hands on; your staff does basic jobs for you(such as simple exhaust repairs/brakes/etc..) More money sinks. Custom build jobs(This may or may not be in newest DLC,if so disregard), not just repairs. Not everything needing worked on is broke. A lot of customers want a built/modified/improved car out of a perfect performing car.

Overall this is an amazing game despite my minor annoyances. Amazingly fun if cars are your thing.  Would recommend to any wrench turner who plays games.

reviewText:
First and foremost: I LOVE THIS GAME. I also loved Gearhead Garage back in the 90's, and I have a background in auto repair, so I maaaaay be biased.

Having played Car Mechanic Simulator 2014, I realized that this team was putting together something very special - something that rekindled a love I haven't experienced since my Gearhead Garage CD stopped working. CMS2014 (last year's game) reminds me of the CD-level release of Gearhead Garage - no auctions, limited cars, and somewhat... unfinished, I suppose. CM2015 (this year's game) is the entry that I think the developers wanted to make. It feels alive, very much so, and it feels like it has this wealth of potential just waiting to be tapped. I am honestly excited for this game in a way I'm not often excited about games.

The ProsDevs are highly active in the community. Seriously, check the Steam Forums for this game, and they're engaged with players. They are actually keeping a community-created list of wanted features (and are honest about what they can't/won't include, too). VERY cool to see this from a dev team!
Gorgeous graphics. The details in the textures are really nice, and the individual parts shine here. It may not break any monitors or redefine any genres, but it definitely is something my graphics card makes veeeery pretty.
Customizable home base" (garage). Maybe it's just a "me thing"

reviewText:
Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 has become one of my favorite games to play, I just can't quit playing it.

The main thing that makes this game fantastic is that it is extremely educational. I began mechanically ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and actually learned a whole lot about the functions of a vehicle.

Pros:

- Beautiful graphics.
- Good car selection. (clearly knockoffs, but you can take a good stab at what they represent)
- Plenty of parts to disassemble and reassemble.
- Doesn't just hold your hand and tell you every move to make. (Some may not consider that a pro)
- Is definitely realistic, and now I can trust myself to change sparkplugs. :p

Cons:

- I learned from this game that the key way to identify a messed up car part is to find the absolutely rusted-over part, and remove it. I believe that if the creator(s) were to create cracked, dented, crushed, and other affects to try to identify, that it would be a little less cheesy, and a lot more challenging.
- No trucks. I will live until this issue is fixed though. :)
- No transmission repair. I feel as if the game has very in-depth repair abilities, such as being able to gut out an engine and lift the whole thing out, but as far as gearbox operations, you don't get to jack with the transmission at all, you only have to replace or repair the gearbox as a whole without messing with the transmission or the overall mechanism inside of the gearbox itself. (I STRONGLY DESIRE THE ABILITY TO DO THIS)

9/10 Absolutely recommended, would be 10/10 if it weren't for a few minor things like what I mentioned above.

Instead of making different parts show that they are worn and broken using a variety of techniques, the game uses only one. RUST.

So imagine we are handed a relatively new car that has some suspension problems. We pop the car on a lift, take a look at the undercarriage, and we find pristine parts, right next to others that look like they've been randomly touched by a rust monster. This makes the game into quite the amusing find the rust" quest.

Added hilarity comes from antique muscle cars. I've opened the hood just to find an engine that must have been submerged in the ocean for 100 years. You want me to fix your engine? reviewText:
I won't claim to know everything about cars, I would struggle to fix a car if someone gave me a step by step 'Fixing a car for dummies' book. That said, this is a good start for anyone remotely interested in fixing/repairing/replacing parts.

While there are some things I could criticize, like the 'instructions not clear enough - private parts stuck in engine block' tutorial, it's quite easy to get into and play with little hand-holding. The part repair system could use a little work imho, the paint shop seems a bit redundant at times, the auction camera needs a bit of fixing, and some other small things.

Overall for a game of this style, having that balance between a gearhead's game and a general indie style game is hard to get right. This game gets it right. It has enough depth and detail to actually make me stop and think about what I'm doing and what steps I should take to complete the repair, but not too much that I have to call my mechanic friends/family and ask them what I need to do.

The game is easy to get into and very fun to play, again balancing gameplay and detail/realism. The number of times I've had to replace a crankshaft after I've already taken apart the clutch housing and reassembled it......

There are a few things that needed work, but mostly just quality of life improvements that could be changed/added in a patch. No major problems to speak of.

I wish some of the 2014 features were there, like the sense of progression from a garage to a multi-car shop, or the 'replace the missing parts from my new used car purchase'.

Yes you will replace brakes a thousand times, yes you will change thousands of filters, yes you will find the same problems coming up time after time. This is the life of a mechanic. Cars need brakes, cars need new filters, mechanical things break, and often times it's the same things that break. I would recommend that you see the 'monotony' as a more realistic representation of how it is to fix cars in a shop. Your car will need new oil, it will need a new timing belt at least once in its life, it's just a fact to live with.

The thing I personally like, having recently gotten to that point, is once you can purchase a parking garage and go to the auto auction to purchase broken down piles of scrap, and turn them into like-new beauties to sell. The trailer/intro video shows this, starting with a car that may be missing half of the body, trying to repair as many parts as possible to save money, and buying what you can't fix. By the end you can decide whether to just replace the really bad parts, or completely renovate the body, engine, and suspension to brand new quality. It adds a sense of accomplishment to the end game (which some may say is desperately needed after changing 1000 brake pads), and keeps you playing.


TL;DR: It can be boring, but it's worth it to anyone even remotely interested in cars. Just buy it. (Though if still in doubt - wait for a sale, $20 USD may be a bit steep for some)

reviewText:
Playway has really done a great job with this one. I enjoyed CMS2014 but they managed to build on that and improve it in almost every way. And all with Kickstarter and a low pledge goal. As the name implies you run an auto shop repair business. But new and improved for 2015 are the cars have many more parts now and the repairs are a good deal more involved. You also earn XP now as you work and complete jobs which can be used to unlock more advanced diagnostic tools like the test path, OBD scanner, compression tester etc and other repair abilities.

There is also an unlockable paint shop now as well so you can do body and paint work and an auction house where you can buy junk cars for parts or fix them up and sell them for profit. Once you earn enough to get the extra parking lot, you can store your cars for service or just collect them. Customers call in on the phone with jobs you can take or decline. An all new better organized parts shop and tablet access eliminates running back and forth to the computer to buy parts.

Test driving the vehicle now and using your diagnostic tools generates a parts list condition report for certain systems saving you time poking around and disassembling the vehicle looking for bad parts.

All in all there's quite a bit to do and highly recommended if you like puzzle games, working on cars, or are a simulator fan.

reviewText:
Somewhere along the history of video games, a beautiful little too-weird-to-live yet too-rare-to-die niche genre was born. Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is smack-dab in the middle of this genre, and can be described as a zen-like puzzler that is an incredibly slow burner. This game will require many hours from you, and will satisfy and reward you the whole way.

Essentially, you manage a mechanics garage. The whole thing. You answer calls, take jobs, and fix cars (among other things). You can repair parts, or order new. You can let jobs pile up, or solve one at a time. Each job is very much a puzzle. The better you are, the quicker you advance. The more you advance, the better swag/tools/speed/etc. you get. It has RPG elements like that. The music is great, too.

Pros:
+Utterly addicting, in all the right ways.
+Beautiful graphics, and great music to fit.
+Metric tons of gameplay in here.
+If you are familiar with automotive anatomy, it will help some, but don't let that scare away people that are unfamiliar: its easy to learn.
+Controls are smooth and intuitive after the first 20 minutes or so.

Cons:
-This is the kind of game (I think) that is best chipped away at an hour a day or so (probably like EuroTruck Simulator). Its a slow burner. You need to invest alot of time to really get somewhere. Not necessarily a 'con', but you should be aware. It isn't instant gratification.

I got it on sale, but I think its worth full price for most people (if you are looking into it, its probably for you). Its amazing and beautiful how video games can be brilliantly built out of mundane and simple ideas.

Peace,

reviewText:
Car Mechanic Simulator 2015:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Every one of us knows about cars to a certain degree. Well, we know which brands of car we like, what shape we like, what features they have and mostly we love to drive them (must be a minimum of 16 years old to do so). That is probably the extent most of us really know about automobiles. Well, Thanks to Car Mechanic Simulator 2015, you will expand your knowledge of one of the biggest inventions of the nineteen century!

Car Mechanic simulator 2015 is a car simulation/ racing / puzzle game. In this game, you are going to take control of a very busy garage. Your phone is going to ring constantly and you will receive a lot jobs to repair cars (mechanics and body work); engine, brakes, suspensions, gearbox, axles or the body of the car. After you accept the job (you will have a full description of the job), you will have to get your hands dirty and reach the part to be replaced. You can’t really miss it, it will be rusty (red). One of the interesting aspects of the job description is that you have to make sure that all parts you replace are of a certain condition (eg above 70%). Well, if you buy the part it would fine but sometimes you might decide to use the repair table to save some money. Let’s say you decide to replace the faulty part with a brand new one and decide to order the part using your desktop. You will have five suppliers and one bank. Each supplier will be a specialist and the bank will be here if you need a loan.

At the end of each job, you will earn money (thank god for that, you see the price of some parts. . . pretty steep) and experience points. As you gain experience, you will be able to accept bigger jobs and each time you reach 1,000 XP you will be given an upgrade point which you can use to get better tools or customize your garage. Xp will also give you access to upgrade you garage with very important features; such as a paint shop. If you feel the urge to take a break from the chaotic work, why don’t you take a car for a spin or go to the auction (you must upgrade your garage with a carpark before you can go to the auction).

The layout of the garage is well designed and you can see everything a garage has to offer – car lifter, tools, garage doors - but no calendar (you know those calendars that have picture of a woman without much on sitting on a car bonnet looking rather suggestive).

The graphics are really good and the controls are a combination of keyboard / mouse and are easy to use and understand. The soundtrack is absolutely stunning, too.

This game is really impressive to be honest with you. Whether you are a petrol head or not, it is really enjoyable to play. It might be a bit repetitive, but it’s fun!

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Good graphics
-	Garage is very well laid out and can be customized
-	Easy to follow jobs in hand
-	Plenty of content and DLC
-	Great soundtrack

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	No achievement or trading cards
-	A bit repetitive

Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is a well thought-out game.

8/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

reviewText:
Highly recommend:

PROS:
-Great fun
-Very relaxing
-Quite easy, dot require you to read through manuals, you can work out everything for yourself while playing which is part of the fun
-Actively developed and improved constantly...
-...while at the same time finished and fully playable
-Awesome contact with the developer on steam forums
-Player feedback is actually considered and implemented.

Cons:
-Gets repetitive
-Quite easy, especially after you've taken apart every type of car, there is no challenge
-No real management layer, 95% of games focus is on taking cars apart and putting them back together.

Explanation:
As it stands it is a lot of fun especially if you like games like World of Guns or taking things apart, maybe learning something in the process, you will love this game. It can get repetitive after about 16h (I played more than 30 already and still have lots of fun), but it is actively developed and almost every week (and sometimes even more often) there is something new to see in the game and also after you explore all the content available at the moment game is still relaxing and fun so I find myself running it just to play for about half an hour, fix a car of two, and relax a little. I highly recommend this game. It is very well done technologically, constantly improved in terms of gameplay and replayability and has very good support and contact with the developer. Almost every thread on steam forums has a developer answer, and some of the suggestions were implemented in the game in literally few days from being first posted. If only more game developers were like creators of Car Mechanic Simulator 2015...

reviewText:
This game is truly what every gear-head has been waiting for. Virtually running your own shop - with a few things missing. I would LOVE to make a few suggestions for the next release so that it would suite not only my own preferences as a Diesel Mechanic, but those as a gamer.

Pros:
Smooth, flawless gameplay. No bugs worth remembering.
BEAUTIFUL textures.
The ability to diagnose with different tools.
Decent car variety (for what the game is)
Auctions!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Build for profit!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Pick what jobs you want to do!
Immersive gameplay.

Cons:
Some things that should need bolts or nuts, don't have them. Making removal easy.
Random pulleys.... (really urks me that the belt is being bent in a way for no purpose other than aesthetics)
No A/C Systems in any cars (would be a fun thing to troubleshoot)
What happened to intake hoses/tubing?
Driveshaft removal in something that is rear-wheel drive is WONKY.
ignition coils can only be seen if you hover over them (possible bug)
Body work system is weird, sometimes get a work order for replacing panels for a vehicle with no paint job, but panels are same color as car. (wtf?)
Music........ oh my god the ♥♥♥♥ing music.

Suggestions:
Advertise this product more for a bigger budget on the next version (you guys are onto something)
More varieties of things to diagnose and troubleshoot (like oil/coolant/fuel leaks)
Add nuts/bolts to things that would typically be bolted down to an engine (like an intake on the older V8)
Employees?
Don't let this series die.... please........ pretty please..... 2016?!?!

reviewText:
Wow, finally a developer that looks at all of the weak points of a previous title and improves upon them - this game has exceeded my expectations so far (only 1.8 hours played at time of posting).

I was so excited for this game when I saw it announced on Kickstarter. I didn't even think twice, of course I backed it, 2014 was such a great game. The idea of Car Mechanic Simulator is a very easy one to understand - I absolutely love tinkering with my real life car so naturally you would think this game is made for someone like me who is looking for a cheaper alternative to modding real cars, I would actually disagree with that. I find that this game has a wider market than people first think - the hunt for that last broken part and the race to get the funds for a bigger garage or that new part for the car you picked up at auction last week adds both puzzle and RPG elements that a lot of gamers will be familiar with and will enjoy.

The game itself plays incredibly well and the new menus are gorgeous, very simple and straightforward, the controls have also been fine-tuned leaving the finished product feeling much better and in turn even more fun to play.

Anyone that has played 2014 and liked it, even just a little bit, should definitely pick this up - let's keep supporting the creators and hopefully we will see another new game with some more incredible new features in 2016!

The only thing that slightly holds this game back is the lack of customisation that you can put into the cars you pick up at auction. I would love to be able to fit my 20 year old rusty hatchback with a 5.0 litre V8, upgrade to a twin exhaust (or even quad!?), a wide body kit, slam the suspension, tint the windows, even possibly convert it to 4WD! Oh, the possibilities... Perhaps I'm just expecting too much, or maybe I've just been playing too much Need for Speed... Who knows, either way, I would bet money that we will see improvements like these in either future DLC or the next release.

Verdict - As much as I really want to give this game a perfect score, it has to be 9/10 based on the lack of customisation for your auction bangers. Still a fantastic game that I will play until my eyes bleed.

reviewText:
You don't have to be a car enthusiast to enjoy this game.  If a 3D puzzle/forensic/tycoon game hybrid appeals to you, you might like CMS 2015. I call AAA to jump my battery, and my eyes glaze over when people talk bout cars, but I was surprised how much joy I got from buying a rusty junker, taking it apart, and either repairing or replacing all of its parts to make it practically brand new.

------
PROS
____

+ Gentle learning curve. I felt like an idiot for the first couple minutes, but even after just the second repair job, I felt a rewarding sense of growth in my abilities.  I don't like working too hard for a game (there's real life for that!), but I get bored when games are too easy, and CMS 2015 hits that sweet spot between boredom and frustration.

+3D puzzle/forensic/tycoon game hybrid.

+ Great music. If you end up buying this game, make sure to walk over to the radio, turn it on, and flip the stations.  I'd pay for at least one of the tracks they play on the game's radio.

+ Active developers as of 4/2015. They seem to respond pretty fast to reported bugs, patch minor gameplay updates that significantly improve the gaming experience, and actually post upcoming plans for future updates.

-------
CONS
-------
+ Longer loading screens than I would've expected, but nothing too frustrating

+ Getting enough experience points and money to get to the more fun parts of the game (going to auctions to buy a junker and build your own car/s, upgrades for work efficiency, etc) might take a bit too long for impatient gamers.

reviewText:
CMS 15 was the first title I played in the series and so far It's incredible fun. At first I was skeptical because I'm not all for simulators but to put it in short, I called in to work to play this non stop for 14 hours. Evidence enough?

The huge plus for this is that the developers actually listen to the feedback and it's astounding. For instance, they released an update on Monday 4/27/15 that introduced tablets but unfortunately that followed a few bugs that altered the quality of the new features and within 8 hours of reporting the bug they had already released a hotfix.

Overall, it's a great game and is worth every penny!

reviewText:
Amazingly addictive game. Even if you're just an enthusiast and not a complete nut about the whole topic of automotives, this game can really suck so many hours out of you by the fuel of your own curiosity and wanting to learn more about automobiles.

Honestly, I can't list anything wrong about this game. Maybe just teeny-tiny details that'll probably be patched later on? That's about it. A big plus I like about this game is that the developers plan on updating and releasing more DLCs down the line, making for even more addicting gameplay of restoring and repairing cars.

To be short, even if you just like cars though you don't know every little thing about them (like I do), this game is worth picking up and at least trying for a number of hours. (Though once you get addicted to the gameplay, expect tens of hours or even more to fly by)

[EDIT]
Adding to the second paragraph, I have to say that it does not show all the tiny little details (i.e. gaskets and such), but it still does a lovely job at showing the basic parts of an engine.

Also, I'd love to see some more interesting features! Engine swaps, turbo add-ons, all those things!

reviewText:
I'm on the fence about this one. I think Car Mechanic Simulator is a tremendous first step, however it ultimately fell short of what I was hoping for.

The game boils down to an interactive set of 3d car models. These models allow you to disassemble and reassemble engines, drive trains, and so on. This is definitely neat, but in itself only has so much enjoyment before things get repetitive.

The illusion of running a repair shop almost works but the finer points of running a business are completely lost. There are always more customers waiting, no matter how long you take, or how poorly you did. Diagnosing problems seems almost trivial, just look for rusty components as you wrench things apart. I want to like this, but I ran out of challenges a while ago. All that remains is the grind of XP and money.

This game needs more of something. I would personally love to see engine tuning and performance simulated to some degree. Other options would be expanding the business model of running a repair shop, or perhaps adding more realism to the repairs themselves. A broken part isn't just a rust texture after all.

Cons:

Minor grouse -- slow loading times

reviewText:
This is a great step forward for the game compared to CMS2014. Massive improvements to graphics, tons more vehicle parts to work with, and a whole new approach to issuing missions makes this a major overhaul to what was already a pretty good game. Despite some worries about hardware, I've been running the game at 2560 x 1600 with maxed out settings and see a solid 60fps.

The idea of having jobs issued by telephone, with the ability to pick and choose your workload, really works well for me. My son and I picked out a couple of interesting looking jobs, loaded them up on the lifts and started plugging away at the pile of problems. The whole process felt very smooth and intuitive. A nicely structured tutorial at the start (very simple, just a few text popups and some easy initial missions) helped greatly.

It's still not as easy as I'd like to navigate around the inside of the vehicle, but since the real thing is even harder I can't complain.

These guys have put out a great game, and they even managed to do it on-schedule. If they hit their published targets for DLC I'll be even more impressed.

Right now their software is massively underpriced in the Steam store, there is no way this game should be priced so low, so jump onto it asap.

reviewText:
Far above and beyond CMS 2014.

Still lacking a little in some areas but is constantly being improved by the Dev's.

I could go into detail but I think plenty of other reviews have done a good job of that already.

The game reminds me sort of like being a puzzle game in a sense.
You're given a problem, such as 'there is a rattling noise in the engine;'
And must find out the cause and remedy it.
Which usually entails replacing a defective part, in my case with the rattling, it was the clutch bearing.

The game starts off easing you in, allowing you to know which parts are needing replacement/repair and giving
you the option to highlight them as well.
Later on however you won't know which parts are wrong but are giving hints. (Steering is wobbly")
And you can put the car through various tests which can help you discover what's wrong.
Drive the car on the Test Course and you might find out the suspension is bad.
Use the OBD Scanner on the car and find out about any electrical problems.
Etc.

Later you can get into auctions and re-selling cars and stuff; but I won't go into detail there.
(mostly cause I haven't reached that far myself yet lol)

The bottom line
hoursPlayed: get this game it's so much better.\nIf you like the idea of mechanics but are on the fence.. I would recommend the game still however if you\nwant to be certain maybe watch some LP's on Youtube or something."

reviewText:
I played CMS 14 and enjoyed it. And only having a brief play on CMS 15 there's a lot of improvements that have been made. I maintain this is a great tool for those who want to get to know parts and the very basic mechanical knowledge on a car.

Having been a grease monkey I know working on motors is just not that easy. (if only!)

There is a steep learning curve, heck, my first job was an engine block replacement! Which meant everything had top be undone, gearbox out, clutch & flywheel out, both manifolds. All fun. Mind you, I have yet to experience pistons and con rods that don't need unbolting from their bottom bearing caps before removing. . (little oversight by the devs there! - but nothing major)

I love the way you can take multiple jobs, but that could lead to confusion if you don't check the job sheet.

I also like the fact that as jobs go on, you have to check & diagnose the faults yourself. Something to look forward to and be a little challenge.

This game, I feel, will just eat away hours, and it's intended not to be stressful, but really a chill out game, like ETS2 or similar.

All in told, if you like the idea of messing about with cars but don't want to get your hands oily, then this is ideal.

reviewText:
This is a huge improvement over Car Mechanic Simulator 2014.  I've owned it for only one week and have 32 hours on the game already (work full time, long commute, activities on the weekends).

If you like to take things apart and build things, or like cars in general, you should check this game out.  It's not so true to life that you would be able to do major work on your own car with only this game as education, but you would learn which parts are which and generally where to find them.

There are many other reviews that do this game more justice than mine, but I wanted to record my yes" vote anyway."

reviewText:
I watched a gameplay video on Youtube for this game and it grabbed my attention instantly. I am a forty something nerd and geek and I enjoy anything to do with mechanics and technology and this simulator looked like the perfect thing for me, to the point that I even updated my desktop pc to handle the graphics.

The game has not dissapointed, I am hooked. I haven't modded the game to increase my XP or money, I have worked through all the telephone jobs I needed so I could unlock everything and start my own car collection. Playing the game this way has shown a great balance of having to earn the money in order to collect the cars from the auction house and renovate them just as you would in real life.

The future potential for this game is exciting, hopefully with a few more DLC licenced cars and maybe other vehicles, a track or two to drive around or being able to upgrade your vehicles with a full engine swap and tune, drive conversion, suspension upgrades, also adding bucket seats and a roll cage to create a perfect race or drift car.

If a new kickstarter campaign was initiated for these additions I would certainly invest.......

reviewText:
http://youtu.be/ADxZMXhIx3A

https://youtu.be/jyUuvZvyyMQ

Farming Simulator, Bus Simulator, Construction Simulator, Grass Simulator, Goat Simulator

There has been a lot of crappy simulator titles filling the steam store page over the last couple of years, but I was quite surprised last year with coming across Car Mechanic Simulator 2014.

The Development Team at Play Way and Red Dot Games were really interested in a lot of the community feedback on the forums and wanted to implement a lot of their ideas by working on either DLC or an update to the game for the fans

Due to funding requirements, they reached out to the community on kickstarter, where they did finally get funding to complete Car Mechanic Simulator 2015

I was one of those backers and am very happy with how it has turned out!

The production value is definately a large increase on the previous 2014 title with
a lot of polish put into the game.

Each car part is lovingly crafted with a beautiful attention to detail.

Even without switching into the Part Examine Mode, you can tell which parts are severely warn by the amount of wear or rust tarnish on the part.

In examine mode, most parts can be visually inspected without requiring the advanced tools needed, but in the case of Electrical Parts, you will need to purchase the diagnostic tool to be able to check or repair the parts.

Later on in the game, you can also purchase a paint bake house and perform panel work as well as a testing line to assist in finding where that annoying little rattle is coming from.

It starts you off in your Garage with the phone ringing to inform that a new job is available

Selecting the phone gives you a list of availalble jobs, being able to accept or decline as you see fit.

So Grab your Imperial Shifter Spanners, Left Handed Screwdrivers and attach your silencer to your rattle gun! It's time to get busy!

Most of the initial starting jobs are simple tasks with parts lists or problem information attached. Like replacing filters, brake pads, Suspension Bushes, wheels and oil.

Moving up to the more advanced areas like replacing Turbochargers, Pistons, Muffler Bearings, Crankshafts, Bottles of Boost and Timing Gear.

The workshop is fitted with 2 Hoists and a central area, giving you the room to work on a couple of cars at the same time. This also allows access to other areas of the car as there is only so much you are able to do from the top of the engine bay.

Repairing Cars are the main focus of making money, but you can also sell the old parts that were replaced for a little extra money.

Once progressed far enough in the game, you have the ability to go to market and buy cars for your own overhauls and sell them at auction. A fantastic distraction on the side of increasingly difficult fault finding and part replacement.

If you have ever been interested in cars, mechanics or even wonder how they all fit together this is a fantastic sim to get you into and learning all about the ins and outs of engines and suspension.

And Maybe, Just Maybe, you might also realise that a few parts I mentioned don't really exist.

reviewText: CMS 2015 is a fun game! It sports better graphics, a slicker interface, improved controls, a deeper career mode, and a better gameplay experience over 2014. In order to unlock additional content (i.e. slicker vehicles, shop improvements, and abilities) you'll have to turn the wrenches a lot longer in order to gain XP. This isn’t entirely a bad thing, as I feel it keeps you coming back for more. The jobs seem to be more varied in both, substance and tasks in order to get you through. However, you’ll see a lot of the same types of vehicles, early on, just in different colors. Despite that, I honestly can’t find much more to complain about. I think the devs did a pretty good job with this outing, and I look forward to seeing what they’ll add to it.

reviewText:
Hours Logged - 44

Okay so I promised myself that'd write an honest review of this game, but only after logging a fair few number hours in order to sure what I was writing is accurate.

The game is a vast improvement on the 2014, more polished, more complicated (Love stripping an engine to find a mystery fault), and a lot more room for potential.

I've logged 44 hours for this game and I'm not even bored, in fact I'm actually finding myself getting more enthralled due to the auction system, and the refurb jobs I currently have in the parking garage.

So in summary:

Pros:-

- The game will always keep you guessing, even after you have got all the add on's for the garage.
- The auction is brilliant, nothing more satisfying than buying a wreck and doing it up.
- The cars you work on well rendered and have actual real world issues.
- The test track is worth its weight in gold.

Cons:-

- The game needs more depth in regards to cars available.
- I've got an over abundance of XP points and nothing to spend them on.
- More DLC as the Youngtimer pack introduced what seems to be a Fiat 500.
- The garage itself needs to be open to change, maybe allowing us to move stuff around.

So in conclusion, this game is good but needs a little more refinement to make it great.

4 out of 5

JB

reviewText:
TL;DR: All in all, a very enjoyable game for anyone, but especially for petrolheads. :-)

I would recommend this game to any petrolhead/car fanatic out there. This is a very refreshing game, since it's the only one of it's kind that I know and it's very casual. For me, it's also a nice way to learn a bit more about the anatomy of cars  on top of the knowledge that I already have (and the fact that the game is translated to my native language also helps a lot, since I'm not too familiar with the English names for various parts). That's probably the downside, you'll need some basic car mechanics knowledge to get going. The tutorial isn't really all that explanatory, so if you're not familiar with the basics, it could take you quite some time to figure out what parts you actually need to replace and that can be frustrating.

But, if you have some basic knowledge you should be fine. You can pretty much pull apart anything until there's just a skeleton standing. That's what makes the game so cool, there are no limits in what you can and cannot do. There are no set time limits for repairs, so if you feel like completely disecting a car, go ahead and do it!

The XP points system keeps the game challenging. You need to unlock certain features to make your life as a mechanic easier like an OBD scanner to read the on board computer for any errors or better tools to be able to take out screws more quickly. The more XP you get, the more challenging jobs you can accept. And with more XP also come sweeter cars, since when you've built up a name for yourself, people with luxury cars also start finding their way to your garage.

- It's mostly a puzzle game for mechanical engineers.  Although even as a newbie to cars, the game helps you a lot, and in the meantime you'll learn a lot about how cars work
- There is test driving of vehicles but no racing" or multiplayer
- The most fun is purchasing vehicles at auctions (fixer-uppers) and restoring them for profitable resale.  Take the extra used parts you gathered from these vehicles and repair customer old beaters for almost no cost to you (also very profitable)

There is some degree of financial management / budgeting aspect in the game but it's minor.  Given the pacing and profitability of jobs coming in

reviewText:
I liked the first car mechanic simulator (2014) but mostly gave up on it pretty early due to not being comfortable with both the interface and how the camera worked in-game. I'm happy to say this years version is just so much better. I've been playing for hours now (ignore the low hours played stat - Steam was down earlier so I played in offline mode) and it's a very entertaining game. Improvements such as the multiple bays, car auctions, upgrade paths - among many others - just make it a more complete game and I am very happy that I backed it on Kickstarter from the start.

I'm only around 15 jobs in and the difficulty has been going up steadily in terms of type of repairs that I'm now being tasked with but - and this is a big but (ahem) - you're left to play the game at your own pace which is perfectly suited for this type of game. I'm having a blast playing this and can't wait to see the later parts of the game once I unlock them.

For the price of £14.99 this game is a steal if you have any kind of interest at all in the basic workings of motor vehicles but I wouldn't expect to become a fully-fledged mechanic after putting a few hours into this. Although, having said that,  it's very likely your basic car knowledge of what parts go where will improve dramatically. I used to work in the automotive industry but in the administration side so this game appealed to me for that reason as well.

As a comparison the nearest thing I can compare CM2015 to is the ancient Gearhead Garage that Snap-on bought out many, many years ago that was a fun, albeit simple, game repairing and doing up cars to flip at auction and make money. I'm hoping this game further in will vastly improve on that little gem from way back.

Highly recommended. Well done to the developers.

reviewText:
Firstly let me just say that I have been wrenching on actual cars, motorcycles and marine engines for many years and I truly enjoy it. I also have really enjoyed mechanic simulators in the past, Street Rod was a staple of my childhood.

Secondly, If you're *really* into car mechanic simulation, buy this, when its on sale. This is better than Car Mechanic Simulator 2014, but still not a great game.

If I had to use one word to describe this game, it would be Tedious.

It takes a very, very long time to unlock the more enjoyable parts of the game (9000xp for the garage, are you kidding me??) You'll find yourself repeating the same monotonous, mind numbing jobs to build your xp before you can unlock things like the test track" and the Garage
date: where you can store your own cars bought at auction. Speaking of which
recommended: the XP system leaves much to be desired and appears to have been thought up in 5 seconds with no play testing whatsoever. Remove a part? +1 XP. Install a part? +1 XP. Finish a job? 100XP. That's pretty much it. I guess you could get 9000XP by removing and installing the same spark plug 4500 times. Replacing a piston should generate orders of magnitude more xp than replacing an oil filter.\n\nYou select the job you wish to take by clicking on your desk phone. It lists 4 jobs
hoursPlayed: 2 of which always require vastly more XP than you have.\n\nThe interface can be painful to operate - Press I to open inventory.. but press Escape to close it? How about the parts catalog
voteText: which is listed in alphabetical order and does not have nearly enough subcategories. An alphabetical list for engine parts with photos is ridiculous.\n\nThe repair bench is a button press. That's it. Remove part
helpfulPercent: attempt to repair
votesHelpful: you'll either make it better or make it worse. Boring mechanic.\n\nThere are definitely lots of parts in the engines
votesTotal: which is great
votesFunny: but the selection of which parts are 'wrenchable' and which are not seems completely arbitrary. Why are there 4 clips holding the airbox together
commentsCount: and like 4 bolts to the entire gearbox? Also please don't force the player to lift and drop the car a bunch of times to work on the engine... some parts are removable from the top
column16: some from the bottom. Why can't I just remove the engine and put it on a test stand?\n\nI realize this review is a bit discombobulated
column17: but then again so is this game. It just seems like a lot of values were randomly selected
column18:
and not much thought was put into vital gameplay mechanics and interface design.

5/10.

Better games in this genre from years past:

* Street Rod 1 / 2
* Redline Legal Street Racing
* Gearhead Garage"

reviewText:
This game is way more fun than it deserves to be. That is a good thing.

Will you learn how to repair a real car? No. But it will give you a rough approximation of where certain parts are located in a car and a general idea of what they could look like. It's essentially a puzzle game. You are told the car has a noise in the engine, you need to find and repair the specific part. As you play you gain access to more testing tools so you can check the current durability of items without needing to fully disassemble the vehicle.

But let's face it, eventually you will fully disassemble a vehicle for the fun of it, because you can.

reviewText:
Good but a bit repetitive - Another relaxing game if you like to have something else to do while you watch TV or listen to the radio/podcasts in the background.

Essentially, you're given a few different 3D jigsaw puzzles which have to take apart, find out which parts are broken (which appear corroded for some reason), replace/repair said parts, and put them back together again (the game shows you where they go).

Optionally, you can perform diagnostic tests on vehicles to make finding broken parts easier, rather than find out for yourself by removing them from vehicles - But I think that also takes away the tiny ammount of challenge that this game has to offer.

It also has XP and Levels to lengthen the content. Earn XP by completing repair jobs on vehicles, and unlock different cars, perks (more diagonstic tools, faster unbolting) and more complex jobs.

There's not a lot to this game and it doesn't demand much of your attention once you've learned the basics, although it's nicely animated and does a good job at showing the very basics of car anatomy. You probably won't learn more than that from playing it, though. It's not an educational tool, if you're expecting it to be one.

reviewText:
Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is a niche game. If you are the type of person who likes to be given a task with little to no info and are told to solve it, this game is right up your alley. However, if you are looking for an action oriented game with constant movement and excitement, this isn't for you.

Pros -
- Huge improvement over the last game. More cars, music, customization options, everything.
- The detail in the cars and garage are very impressive, and each car, while having similar builds, are different from one another
- Very immersive. Hours can slip by before as you work on cars
- Very accesible to everyone, you don't have to know a ton about cars to play this game

Cons  -
- The music. Even though it has more music than the previous, it still is a bit shallow in number of tracks. Also, they're all dubstep, and if your not into that (I am) , you might have to play with the volume off
- It is hard to play for extended periods of time, and it can quickly become Bolt Unscrewer Simulator 2015

reviewText:
The game itself isn't going to really teach you much about cars or trucks that you can take and apply to the real world. You will learn some basic names and functions that are pretty basic so I wouldn't really call it much of a sim. It doesn't take long to reach the maximum level and money isn't a real obstacle once you can afford to buy, repair/upgrade, and sell your first vehicle.

Where this game becomes a gem though is how relaxing it is. It has good music and decent graphics that you don't get tired of looking at. Everything is straight forward and not hard to figure out. More and more options and car varieties come out to keep you entertained. Where the game is now (May 15, 2016) is pretty great. You have a drag strip (super cars struggle a bit here) and a Dyno setup to help tune" your car to maximum performance. You have a small but nice variety of cosmetic options to make your car more valuable and unique. This plus all of the original features gives you a game you can sink a couple of hours into here and there to build up your personal collection and your bank account.

All in all

reviewText:
So far, this is my favorite game of 2015. It expands on everything it did in the first installment, while also not deviating too far from its original style.

For the hardcore car mechanics out there, this game is more for you than CMS 2014. It legitimately has the level of detail that can be beneficial to guys who already know what they're doing.

To those who don't know a lot about cars, get this game and read some guides about what you're looking at and CMS could legitimatly teach you some things.

This developer has it together and I am looking forward to even greater levels of depth in the future with the already amazing build system they have in place.

reviewText:
This game is fun and a good tool for locating and replacing parts of a car.  I have some experience in auto repair and other misc. hardware as I'm a maintenance mechanic for the USPS.  Since I'm no expert in repairing cars and I like to learn, I enjoy this game and I've learned quite a bit from the repair jobs I've done so far.

At the time of this review I'm only a few hours into it but already I notice some things I would like to see added for extra realism.  For example, hoses (air, radiator and others) battery cables and other major wires, various fluids like washer, brake, transmission etc. and gaskets in the engine would be a nice touch.

Something else that would help with the immersion would be to have different size wrenches and sockets with ratchets to use on different size bolts and nuts.

I think it's important to have a lot of different parts for the different cars as most cars take different parts in real life; at least for the larger more important parts.  That would be nice to have to look up the make/model in the computer to get the right part. :)  Honestly I don't think it wouldn't be that hard to add that if only they added part numbers to the car part inventory.  Finally I would like to see options of stock, upgraded and high performance parts so you can upgrade the cars you buy.  Overall though the game has potential to take many hours of fun and learning.  Recommended.

reviewText: I have played both of the car mechanic simulators, and I have to say, this one is better in every single way. And you can't ever complete this one, because jobs are unlimited and randomly generated. This game is very addictive, and it feels a lot like euro truck simulator 2 but with fixing cars instead of delivering cargo. This is not one of those crappy simulators you usually see on steam, this is amazing like euro truck simulator 2. Also, you can modify the colors of your workshop, buy attachments like a paint shop, a test area and a parking garage where you can store your car collection. You gain exp from working on cars, and with it, you unlock more cars with more problems to work on, more attachments to buy for your workshop, and you get upgrade points to upgrade your character, and to get tools to help you identify problems with cars. There's a lot more cars in this one than in 2014, and they are much more detailed with much more parts. This time you can work on the cooling system, open up the engine block and replace pistons or the crankshaft and the crankshaft bearings and everything. This game has insane amounts of detail, and the graphics and textures are mind blowing. The reflections are also really nice. The game also runs really smooth, and you don't even need the recommended graphics card if you want to run the game on Ultra graphics settings. I run it on Ultra very smoothly with my GTX 560 TI 2GB Phantom graphics card, so yeah. I honestly have never seen such gorgeous textures and reflections in a game before.  Well, Gta V has nice reflections, but still, this game is gorgeous too. In this game you can not only work on the parts of your car, but also on the panels, like doors, fenders, bumpers, lights, etc. Also, this game has tons of free DLC coming out, and they look like they will be amazing! The game's soundtrack is pretty cool too, even though I'm not really a fan of dubstep, I enjoy the game's dubstep soundtrack. It gets repetitive after a while though, because there's not a lot of songs in the game. I would like it a lot if they add more songs, and perhaps also a custom radio thing where you use your own music for the game's playlist. At the moment when I feel like using my own music, I turn off the game's soundtrack in the options menu, and run my playlist in the background, but I think it would be awesome if they added an in-game feature to use your own music, so you don't have to turn off music in the options each time you want to listen to something else. This game is also well worth the $20, and I highly recommend you buy it!

reviewText: Car Mechanic Simulator 2015. You can get rid of almost every part of your car, test your cars, sell them, even go to the Auction House and buy rusted, busted cars. The best part: Fix them and sell them for a WHOLE CHUNK OF MONEY. Also, there is a Garage, Paint Shop, and Diagnostic Test for your cars when you have enough XP. Store your cars in the Garage. Paint your cars in the Paint Shop. Test your car faster on the Diagnostic Test. I'd recommend this game to you. This game may seem a bit expensive, but it's definitely worth the $19.99 you have to pay. I'd buy it if I were you.

reviewText:
This is a fantastic game. If you like to work on cars.

If you played car mechanic sim 2014, you know what you're in for, but now engines are detailed. Pistons, Crankshafts, Pushrods, Camshafts, all can now be disassembled. There's also bodywork that can be fixed, more engine configurations, This is essentially a direct upgrade of 2014. There's now an auction mode, and the devs have been stedialy releasing content as the game goes along.

The only negative is you still can't rotate the camera on an axis.

If you like working on cars, This game is worth a buy.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As someone completely devoid of knowledge in mechanics, I can tell you that CMS2015 has taught me a LOT. It isn't as deep as it could be but it still can give you a basic notion if you play it and keep a tab open in your web browser to further study what you see in the game. I even managed to replace my car's air intake and air filter by myself =D .

Basically you have to fix your customers' car, stripping down the car until you find what the problem is. You can use a number of tools to ascertain which parts are faulty or you can drive the car down a test track. You will have to purchase or attempt to fix the part by yourself, replace it and build it up again. You can also buy used vehicles and restore it, but it gets kinda pointless since there's nothing to do with it apart from photographing it and selling it.

It's very casual and gets repetitive fast but still very fun to play. Recommended  for mechanics wannabes =P

reviewText: Its a good game, but there could be some improvements made. Less detail in some areas, oil draining for example, the margin for where the drain pan is small, make that bigger. The way you disassemble and reassemble, you should be able to take off multiple parts at one time. A parts cupboard or something similar would be good to store repaired and used parts rather than have all parts mixed in together. A colour palette for the paint shop rather than a slider for hue etc It takes ages to collect XP. More toolbox upgrades. Timing and carb tune up options. Tyre options. A dyno tuner as well maybe. Trade cars with friends maybe, or race them. Theres so much more that can be done with this game. For now Im giving it 6 out of 10, only because there is so much room for improvment, I hope the creators keep working on this game to make it better.

reviewText:
As someone who knows hardly anything about the inside of a car, it seems very accurate. The names of the individual car parts are accurate.
Whilst playing through the game you will learn teh very basics of the car parts, what they do and how they work.
The overall game is great for people new to cars who want to learn and play at the same time.
With enough time playing the game I would probably feel comfortable enough changing the brake pads on a car and possibly adding new oil.

One major problem I have with the game is the loading time. If I have two cars in the garage and load up the it will take a good minute to load the game, then the first car and then finally the second car.
When taking jobs, loading in the cars also takes quite some time.
It can become quite boring waiting for the cars to load and it's the one thing making me want to close the game down and play EuroTruck Simulator 2 which quicker loading screens.

reviewText:
I supported this game on kickstarter and I am very glad that I did support it.

Here is my first impression and live gameplay on ULTRA high settings:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VEXMxRsDuNI

Ok well let's start quickly by saying if you played CMS2014 you will love this game, if you didn't play CMS2014 you will still love the game ;)
I played lots and lots CMS2014 and couldn't wait for this game to come out.

So what is the main difference between CMS2014 and CMS2015?
Good quesion, but easy to answer.
Everything is different ;)

Lets start with graphics. Briliant, Absolutely superb graphics to the last detail. 5star

Next, gameplay. Gameplay its similar to CMS2014 but improved a lot ( specially camera movements ) everything its a lot easier. 5star

Next, parts. Car has A LOT MORE parts specially engine is absolutely design to the the last screw. Unlike in CMS2014 you can take whole engine apart, so you looking at more than 200+ parts per car. but I will try to take car apart and confirm this*. 5star

The garage and whole enviroment looks so real it will make you speechless. 5star

You can buy very cheap cars on auction and repair them put them together and sell them making lots of profit.

And off course you can upgrade you garage tools and to get more cars in at once.

Does game have any cons/something what needs improving? So far I haven't find anything bad ;) sorry my fault, I found 1 word in tutorial what supposed to be by" and it was "my" so only this so far

Final verdict? 5 star game so very good price with absolute superb graphics and gameplay with lots and lots parts and you can use to learn bit about cars and engine ( kind of ) gives you idea what is where and roughly how to repair it :D

I hope this is good enough to change your mind and you buy a game and enjoy it ;)

Good luck and have fun"

reviewText:
Very complete and real simulator! They should encourage kids to play this at school, learning so much. At the beggining is tricky and if you don't have at least some knowledge you will end up deasambling the whole car and assembling it again. As long as you know how an oil change is done and you are familiar on where some parts are located you should be fine. And if you get stuck in a job o get frustrated you can abort it without any penalties and then try different car jobs. After playing bread simulators, goat simulators, survivals of all kinds... I think this is the most and way far best simulator I ever played. 10/10... Of course if you are not a pretolhead or not interstead in mechanic or learning this game is not for you.

+PROS:
+you get jobs
+you buy car parts
+sometimes you need to examine the car and find out what is wrong with it (far more easy than it sounds)
+remove/place parts one by one, screw by screw
+get paid
+buy tools and upgrades to improve your job
+as more experience you make the more challenging and complex the game gets and more FUN
+awesome electronic/EDM background music
+no bugs found yet, exept once I removed a part and got it twice which is nice.
+repair parts
+sell parts
+and more (yet for me to discover)

-CONS
-you can get stuck on a job, but you can quit it and recover
-some parts are so small and difficult to find sometimes but thats part of being a mechanic simulator
-needs patience
-need to be intersted on cars or the science behind them (specific audience)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The visuals and gameplay mechanics are really good, once you get the hang of them, they feel very natural. At it's core the game is about finding faulty parts and replacing them with new parts. The challenge comes by not knowing which parts need replacing, and finding them using different techniques and tools you unlock along the way. There is also an auction system where you can buy cars, repair them, then keep them or sell them for a profit.

One thing I really wish they had is some description of what each part does in the car. I have the basic understanding of how an engine works, but even the smallest blurb would have been helpful and a nice addition to the budding mechanic in all of us.

Now for nitpicking, would it have killed them to put in a buy button to the work order? As of now you have remember the required part, switch to your tablet and find the part to buy. How about an indication of whether you already own the part? Instead you again have to remember the part, switch to your inventory and search it up. Sure, it's a simulator, that's part of the game, but it does get quite tedious and distracting when you have to search 20 different parts individually.

Lastly sit down and be ready, unlocking everything is quite a grind, though personally I don't mind, I find it oddly meditative.

reviewText:
This game is pretty good.   During the beginning it has cars with list of exactly whats broken, which is simple as deconstructing parts to find broken ones.  You then replace them with parts you buy instantly on the shops computer.  You later can update to tablet to buy parts right under car(saves time)

You eventually you get good enough that game will no long hold your hand to what is wrong with the car.  There is car test park, with driving  stages to test certain parts of car(I personally never used it).

You eventually rack up experience and money to buy cars at the auction house, where you buy bombed out vechicles, often missing body parts.  This is coolest part and you can eventually fill your garage with cool cars with custom colors.  My goal filling my garage with all the mmoore interesting cars.

PRO's
Pretty fun after you get tons of experience
Ok graphics(good but  not great)
Lots of different cars
Auction House
Really teaches you about cars!!!
Somewhat detailing of major car systems
You decide what cars to fix on the phone
Future player mods and DLC
Only $20!


CON's
Experience points take way to long too rack up
May not be super detailed depiction of car(no ac compressors,  no brake lines or bleeding, etc.)
Doesnt tell you everything important(that you can move a oil collection tank under car to avoid $100 cleaning fee or need certain tools for automated testing for parts.
Limited to no customization of cars(at very least make certain wheels interchangable, metallic and matte paint, striping.
No free range walking of car garage(why not!)
No drag strip! ;)

....Biggest Gripes
I used a cheat program to get experience and even money.  I think game should have difficulty modes, like easy where experience points are gained way faster, a lot more starting money, maybe $10000 emergency loan.  You take the fun out of the game for certain players, forcing some players to advance at such a low pace leads to cheating ;). Game mode would let less tech savy players choose slow pace or fast pace.


90/100....Buy Now!!!

reviewText:
Very complete and real simulator! They should encourage kids to play this at school, learning so much. At the beggining is tricky and if you don't have at least some knowledge you will end up deasambling the whole car and assembling it again. As long as you know how an oil change is done and you are familiar on where some parts are located you should be fine. And if you get stuck in a job o get frustrated you can abort it without any penalties and then try different car jobs. After playing bread simulators, goat simulators, survivals of all kinds... I think this is the most and way far best simulator I ever played. 10/10... Of course if you are not a pretolhead or not interstead in mechanic or learning this game is not for you.

+PROS:
+you get jobs
+you buy car parts
+sometimes you need to examine the car and find out what is wrong with it (far more easy than it sounds)
+remove/place parts one by one, screw by screw
+get paid
+buy tools and upgrades to improve your job
+as more experience you make the more challenging and complex the game gets and more FUN
+awesome electronic/EDM background music
+no bugs found yet, exept once I removed a part and got it twice which is nice.
+repair parts
+sell parts
+and more (yet for me to discover)

-CONS
-you can get stuck on a job, but you can quit it and recover
-some parts are so small and difficult to find sometimes but thats part of being a mechanic simulator
-needs patience
-need to be intersted on cars or the science behind them (specific audience)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The visuals and gameplay mechanics are really good, once you get the hang of them, they feel very natural. At it's core the game is about finding faulty parts and replacing them with new parts. The challenge comes by not knowing which parts need replacing, and finding them using different techniques and tools you unlock along the way. There is also an auction system where you can buy cars, repair them, then keep them or sell them for a profit.

One thing I really wish they had is some description of what each part does in the car. I have the basic understanding of how an engine works, but even the smallest blurb would have been helpful and a nice addition to the budding mechanic in all of us.

Now for nitpicking, would it have killed them to put in a buy button to the work order? As of now you have remember the required part, switch to your tablet and find the part to buy. How about an indication of whether you already own the part? Instead you again have to remember the part, switch to your inventory and search it up. Sure, it's a simulator, that's part of the game, but it does get quite tedious and distracting when you have to search 20 different parts individually.

Lastly sit down and be ready, unlocking everything is quite a grind, though personally I don't mind, I find it oddly meditative.

reviewText: Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 does exactly what it says on the box, giving you the experience of being a car mechanic. As a simulator it’s exceptionally well done, capturing many of the aspects of car repair whilst not being as unforgiving as its real world counterpart is. However some of the more interesting parts of the game are hidden behind the levelling system which is too basic and takes far too long to get anywhere meaningful making it very easy to put the game down and forget about it. I enjoyed my time with Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 however if you don’t have an interest in cars or simulator type games then you probably wouldn’t find much more to love in it.\n\nRead my full review here: http://www.therefinedgeek.com.au/index.php/2015/05/11/car-mechanic-simulator-2015-well-theres-your-problem/

reviewText: A wonderful improvement over CMS2014. You can really see that this was a project that meant a lot to the devs by how actively it's supported and how amazing it was right out of the door.\n\nThere is a wide variety of cars, and more being added all the time. The ability to mix things up and restore cars instead of just repairing other peoples cars is lots of fun. You can finally full disassemble engines and just about every other component on the vehicle. The upgrade path may be limited, but the upgrades are worthwhile. The game looks great and runs smooth. If you had high hopes for Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 but were a little disappointed, please try this game, there's no doubt you will be happy with how awesome it is to rebuild classic muscle cars, modern sports cars, compacts, and just about everything else as well as taking on the ever changing challenge of vehicle repairs.
