reviewText:
I'm not sure why I got this game as I have little knowledge with cars beyond regular maintenace. At first it was a little intimidating working on my first few orders but it starts you off with simple things like replacing Fuel, Air, and Oil filters, and other simple tasks. Then you begin to work with different vehicles and much more complicated issues where you will need to competely break down the powertrain.

Of course it's much more simple and MUCH faster than in real life, but it's been a lot of fun so far. Especially with the unlockable upgrades such as unlocking a Paint room, and getting more tools for diagnosising problems, and being able to repair parts efficently without ordering new ones.

I'm still pretty new to the game with a few hours of gameplay, but I think it's a lot of fun. The visuals are great, the sounds of a car lift going up and down are great, as well as the music.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: For those who know close to nothing about cars, and what goes into them, what minor but vital components are needed to make a vehicle run, this simulation CMS '15, would be great for many people. Now, the only part(s) I'm disappointed about, is the lack of vehicle modifications that can be performed. Unlike real life, you can't turbocharge, supercharge, procharge any of the vehicles in this game. Another part I'm not so pleased with about this simulation, is there are no pickup trucks whatsoever. I hope that in the near future there will be DLC containing pickup trucks, vans, and other miscilaneous vehicles. One other Disappointment I have is the amount of driving, or lack of driving ability there is. It would have been nice to have freerome, a race track other than the Factory Test Track, and a Dyno in the Garage. But overall this simulation is pefect for beginners that want to go into the automotive trade.

reviewText:
As someone who knows hardly anything about the inside of a car, it seems very accurate. The names of the individual car parts are accurate.
Whilst playing through the game you will learn teh very basics of the car parts, what they do and how they work.
The overall game is great for people new to cars who want to learn and play at the same time.
With enough time playing the game I would probably feel comfortable enough changing the brake pads on a car and possibly adding new oil.

One major problem I have with the game is the loading time. If I have two cars in the garage and load up the it will take a good minute to load the game, then the first car and then finally the second car.
When taking jobs, loading in the cars also takes quite some time.
It can become quite boring waiting for the cars to load and it's the one thing making me want to close the game down and play EuroTruck Simulator 2 which quicker loading screens.

reviewText:
I think that 6 hours are enough for me to write this review...

CMS 2015 Is a great step forward from the 2014.

If you like cars in overall, you will love this game.

Pros and cons:

+You can own cars and you can make them look as you want.
+The overall look of the parts is great.
+you don't need to remove the whole exhaust to replace a manifold
+tablet system (you can buy the part that you want anywhere, at any time)
+upgrades and upgrade points
+more scanners
+you can change exterior parts (even lights)!
+much more parts to replace

-oil drain can be sometimes hard to operate with
-Too much XP needed to have something. example: 9000 XP to have parking, or 1000XP for a 1 point.

i would give 9.9/10.

reviewText:
Wow, really an awesome game.
At first, you really need to work out how every section of a car assmebles and works, like engine, suspension, brake, exhaust system, that could cost you some time and you need to have some enthusiasm about cars. But after you`ve figured out all these, this game will definitely make you spend some time on it. I usually play 4-5 hours every time...Besides, when you have enough money and experience to play with the auction system, congrats, you have reached the top level of the game, and watching the car that was utterly rubbish when you bought it turning into brand new shiny one, you would have the sense of achievement.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm not sure why I got this game as I have little knowledge with cars beyond regular maintenace. At first it was a little intimidating working on my first few orders but it starts you off with simple things like replacing Fuel, Air, and Oil filters, and other simple tasks. Then you begin to work with different vehicles and much more complicated issues where you will need to competely break down the powertrain.

Of course it's much more simple and MUCH faster than in real life, but it's been a lot of fun so far. Especially with the unlockable upgrades such as unlocking a Paint room, and getting more tools for diagnosising problems, and being able to repair parts efficently without ordering new ones.

I'm still pretty new to the game with a few hours of gameplay, but I think it's a lot of fun. The visuals are great, the sounds of a car lift going up and down are great, as well as the music.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: For those who know close to nothing about cars, and what goes into them, what minor but vital components are needed to make a vehicle run, this simulation CMS '15, would be great for many people. Now, the only part(s) I'm disappointed about, is the lack of vehicle modifications that can be performed. Unlike real life, you can't turbocharge, supercharge, procharge any of the vehicles in this game. Another part I'm not so pleased with about this simulation, is there are no pickup trucks whatsoever. I hope that in the near future there will be DLC containing pickup trucks, vans, and other miscilaneous vehicles. One other Disappointment I have is the amount of driving, or lack of driving ability there is. It would have been nice to have freerome, a race track other than the Factory Test Track, and a Dyno in the Garage. But overall this simulation is pefect for beginners that want to go into the automotive trade.

reviewText:
A great, very simple game. It takes a short bit to get used to how it works and what issues go to which part of the car. If you're very car savy then this will be a walk in the park for you and it'll just serve as a fun simulation to work on some sweet rides. Others, like me, who just know how to change the oil in our cars...if that, will actually find this educational as well as fun. A game like this could have easily been too complicated for people to enjoy, but they hit it right on the button. The graphics are nothing to complain about either!

The only complaint I have is that after awhile you start to see that a lot of the jobs are quite repetitve. It would be nice to have more variety of issues to solve with the cars. Thats pretty much it.

9/10 Great game

reviewText:
Awesome game. It won't teach you to be a mechanic - but you will tinker with the basic components of how a car works.

In the game you will have to find and replace damaged parts, and as you become proficient at this you will have to start diagnosing whats broken. You can also try repairing parts to save dough. To make life easier, you will buy a variety of tools to test the car to find what's wrong, to make repairing go faster, etc.

This game is a huge jump from the last version - and so if you like car games you should buy this for two reasons: a) it's a good game and b) the developers are really showing their skill and passion for this series; so they really deserve some support.

+ decent graphics
+ innovative gameplay
+ excellent improvement over the last version
+ interesting DLCs at fairly reasonable prices

- sometimes confusing upgrade system
- could use more cars
- body work not has comphrehensive as engine and undercarriage systems

tl;dr; if you have even a passing interest in cars, repairing them, etc - this is a great game.

reviewText:
I know nothing about cars other than my general knowledge of mechanical engineering. Cars were never an interest to me, and if something is wrong with my car, I always take it to someone to fix- never would I do it myself. Not even an oil change.

That introduction aside, I LOVE this game. Even without that real-world interest level, this game is polished, sharp, and always has you eyeing goals in the future without holding your hand.  How rewarding it was when I was first repairing some more difficult issues, and without knowing where some parts were located, stripped down the entire engine of a car looking for those parts only to have to reassemble the whole thing- and get it right! It really is a great balance between simulating the work of a mechanic and gamifying it so that it's not quite so world-dreary and labor intensive.

I am quickly banking cash and gaining experience with excitement, as soon in game I'll be able to buy a beat-up car at auction and fix it up to resell for huge profit as a side project in my garage.

If you don't know cars, but enjoy simulations, progress, and have a bit of a mechanical-puzzle oriented mind, this is a very, very well done game and I highly recommend it. I may not be a mechanic after this, but at least my eyes won't cross in ignorance when someone says catalytic converter" to me at the garage.

Side note: I love the music in this game too. A great mix for working away at the cars in game."

reviewText:
Well where do I start? It can be huge fun and it can a bit frustrating if you want to know how to take an engine apart in a simulation get it.
It is a knee deeper in technical terms compared to 2014. Less duct work but diagnostics is harder. Still it is fun taking a whole engine apart replacing one piston, you can do it time and time again.

The great features I like are :
Engines are done superbly to the detail.
Body work a new feature also includes a paint job. Not bad.
Auctions - I love those I am already building a full garage of cars
The developers - I´m not sure if it was me but they fixed a very frustrating issue of having to go to the computer when you want to order a spare part by adding a tablet.
Cars - many of them resemble the real life ones I found even the one I own. You can get from old american muscle cars through japanese cars, german premium cars, SUV, to classics like Maluch and that one is in real detail I had some fun getting that to work. Dear developers hand on heart do you own it?
Music - quite original I like dubstep hehe :) (not just dubstep there of course)
Workshop expansions - nice you can unlock a testing rig and a paint shop.
Practical details - clock showing the current time for example.

And as for most games there is also a huge space for improvement, according to steam forums all the things I miss in the game (tuning, proper race track, multiplayer etc.) are being worked on.

reviewText:
Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is a solid improvement over 2014.  The amount of destructable parts you have is much better than before.  I like that you can now restore cars and work on their bodywork too.  The possibility of DLC should keep the game fresh with new challenges and vehicles unlike 2014 where once you have taken apart a v6 that was really it, game mastered time to move on.  I would recommend this game to people who are curious to see how cars fit together (all be it in a very simplified fashion).   However there are some drawbacks which I hope they iron out soon.

1.  The music is annoying and repetitive, please add more stations and the ability to play my mp3s.
2.  Colouring things rusty to indicate their condition really gives the game away.  I rarely need to use diagnostic equipement or test drives to isolate the problem.  Also, please stop giving me a list of things I need to replace, this compounds the issue. The whole point of the game to test my diagnostic skills and therefore the xp I get at the end of each job.
3.   Using xp to unlock the ad-ons to your workshop like parking, paint booth and test path is stupid.  These should only be based on cash.  The whole xp to unlock thing puts the new car restoration part of game out of reach until the very end (9000xp = 100+ jobs) as you need to unlock the garage parking in order to visit the auctions.  I want to be able to buy a car and work on it slowely as money, skill and ad-ons allow.
4.  Turning down jobs/doing a poor doesn't have consequences (except some xp)?!? are you kidding me? Customer rep needs to play a greater part.  As I recall there were repeat customers in CM2014 if my memory serves me correctly.
5.  Tutorial needs to be bigger.  This is the part of the game where you give me a list of things that are wrong.  Also, put it outside the campaign.  If people are still struggling to to find things in the campaign perhaps introduce Workshop manuals that can be bought via the PC or Tablet???

Well thats enough of the negatives, all in all I still enjoy the game and for only $20 I really think you cant go wrong.  It is different and thats why I like it.  I think the community and the developers will inmprove this game as times goes on.  Get on it.

reviewText:
Incredibly fun game providing a good load of knowledge about car mechanics - instant fav!
I remember playing Street Rod on C64 a long time ago where I could tinker around the car in a very limited way and I loved it.
I'm interested in classic cars (now we have the second classic in my family) and that involves lots of real life mechanical repairs and/or adjustments which made me really curious about how to deal with certain mechanical problems.
I'm extremely happy to have this game and getting a better overall view of the whole picture through it.
Now it' much easier for me to approach towards any upcoming problmes of my classic :)
CMS 2015 is literally an interactive learning material combined with game elements.

Great thing, don't miss it!

Update:
I got my first complete restoration finished: a Bolt Reptilia" (which is a Corvette literally) - it was a frenetic experience. Taking it apart bit by bit
date: remove every single part possible and rebuild it to a shiny 100% condition is just like a pilgrimage. The chrome is fantasic under the hood! And also I guess this is how far the game can go really but repeating this over and over again is a joy."

reviewText:
Well where do I start? It can be huge fun and it can a bit frustrating if you want to know how to take an engine apart in a simulation get it.
It is a knee deeper in technical terms compared to 2014. Less duct work but diagnostics is harder. Still it is fun taking a whole engine apart replacing one piston, you can do it time and time again.

The great features I like are :
Engines are done superbly to the detail.
Body work a new feature also includes a paint job. Not bad.
Auctions - I love those I am already building a full garage of cars
The developers - I´m not sure if it was me but they fixed a very frustrating issue of having to go to the computer when you want to order a spare part by adding a tablet.
Cars - many of them resemble the real life ones I found even the one I own. You can get from old american muscle cars through japanese cars, german premium cars, SUV, to classics like Maluch and that one is in real detail I had some fun getting that to work. Dear developers hand on heart do you own it?
Music - quite original I like dubstep hehe :) (not just dubstep there of course)
Workshop expansions - nice you can unlock a testing rig and a paint shop.
Practical details - clock showing the current time for example.

And as for most games there is also a huge space for improvement, according to steam forums all the things I miss in the game (tuning, proper race track, multiplayer etc.) are being worked on.

reviewText: I got last years game and decided to buy the 2015 version straight away. It's a good game!. Sometime a job will come along in the game and your be taking a lot of the car apart just to find that one faulty part. A basic knowlegde of cars is needed but you will learn fairly quickly about how to take the parts on and off and in what order.  Everything in the game is very decent or better, the sound. the graphics, the gameplay and so far i haven't come across any bugs. There's quite a few extra 'help' in the game like the OBD scanner or a test brake/suspension place in your garage but they cost one experience upgrade which is 1,000 XP in the game, It takes quiet a while to level up, so there's no way your get everything without some hours put in. My biggest problem with the game is the repairs list. You can only see what you need to replace on a list while near the car, once you go to the computer to buy new parts that list is gone. It can be very annoying traveling back and forth to the car to see what you need or you have forgotten. I do know once you unlock repair the items on a bench yourself, you won't need the list as much but i feel the repair list should always be available by pressing O, no matter where you are. Overall i'd give this game a 8/10.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
CMS 2015 basically takes the 2014 version and improves it. They have different vehicles but more of them and somewhat more detail such as body panels, radiators and fans etc that sort of thing. I have enjoyed playing it though imo there doesn't seem to be much of a challenge financially as it's pretty much a continuous upward climb towards riches. At 9000 xp (7ish hrs for me) you unlock the abillity to buy cars in various conditions and fix them up which is fairly rewarding and has greater financial risk/reward if you don't manage your funds.

All in all I wish the game was more detailed (ex. piston heads don't require removing bolts from underneath to remove, many bolted parts are simplified, no fasteners on body parts, only fluid you deal with is oil, so no coolant, trans, gas, wiper fluids etc all omitted, no hoses, no tuning, no interior parts, no glass repair etc. However it is still a fun game, and somewhat educational though simplified.

TLDR; If you are interested in car mechanics you'll like this game, it isn't ultra detailed but it has enough to be fun and challenging at times. Do not expect 100% accuracy to real life.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Being early in the release of the game and with dlc on the way, this game has impressed me and got me hooked, waiting for more...

The detail of the cars is amazing, and while I thought it would be boring, I found myself hooked playing it for the last 4 days.  Troubleshooting and repairing vehicles is recreated in this game, however to a slightly limited scale.

If I had to nit pick problems with their product here, it would be only that it is too basic. The idea that you canrebuild a car with a ratchet and socket is unrealistic, and I would like it if they added usable hand and power tools in the future. First and foremost in my mind should be a torque wrench, where you have to look up torque specs and sequence (could be done using the computer?) and having to set the torque value on the wrench and torque in sequence. welders and paint guns could also be neat to use when doing body work or painting. I think automatic transmissions would also be a must add.

Im sure some of these features will come in time, but as of right now, im fairly pleased with the game. Id recommend it to any car guy or gear head in an instant.

reviewText:
I played their first game, Car Mechanic Simulator 2014.

It's neat. Don't get me wrong, you do stuff so fast in the original and in this newer version. However, it's neat to learn part names, and see the inner workings of vehicles.

I'm so far enjoying the game. Also duely note, the amount of bolts and stuff you have to take off a vehicle would vary greatly in reality.

However it is a simulation game, and no simulation is precise (100%). I still think, they did an excellent job though.

It's got so much more options in this one, compared to the first one and it's alot better optimized for gaming cards.

The first one felt really sluggish at times, though i may of been using an older video card then than what i got now.

Not entirely sure, but it's need to see the cad like shadow underlays of parts you remove (3D view) of the car parts and stuff.

Very fun, i recommend this game to anyone who likes working on their automobile in their free time or are already a mechanic. (though for mechanics some that aren't really happy with their jobs may not like playing this) but the ones that are truly in love with mechanics and automobile industry will likely find it entertaining.

I hopefully will get into mechanic field someday, but its hard to say when that will be.

Great game thus far Playway!

reviewText: This is one of those zen type games.  It draws you in and you just kind of lose yourself in playing around with the cars, removing parts, seeing what connects to what and how and then fixing everything and putting it all back together again. It's kind of like when you're a little kid and want to take apart your toys or the toaster or a radio but here you don't have to worry about mom or dad smacking you when you can't put it back together again.  Not sure how realistic the game is in terms of learning how cars actually work but it's really fun and you can easily lose an hour playing it before you realize.  Definitely worthwhile.

reviewText:
I'll recommend this game because I had fun playing it and it's a better game than I could ever make, but just beware this is far from reality (more of a game than simulator). After a while I got annoyed with some minor things:

The loading times in this game are absolutely terrible, as others have already mentioned.
The sound effects get old pretty quick (sounds like breaking glass every time you remove a bolt or part), can be fixed by turning your sound off but I'd rather have more variety.
The jobs get repetitive, but this happens in real life too (90% of the jobs I received were brake and timing related)
The automatic mouse centering is pretty annoying every time you open a menu
It lacks a lot of realistic parts to be a simulator (transmission gears, more body options, missing almost every electronic part besides the ignition and battery, torque specs, etc) but I suppose someone could fix this with a mod or something.
No Steam achievements (could be some for fully restoring a car, completing certain number of jobs etc)
Everything damaged" is rusted so it's pretty obvious to find the problems without running any diagnostics

I didn't do much with the 1/4 mile strip since each time I went there it was terrible on keyboard and the loading times just weren't worth it. The only thing I ever left the garage for was the auctions and even those just ticked me off. Who would want to pay $50
date: 000 for a rusted piece of garbage that they're only going to get $70
recommended: 000 after fully restoring it? They should make the bidding system a bit more realistic too..\n\nOther than that I liked the game
hoursPlayed: the DLC make it much more enjoyable once you run out of things to do."

reviewText:
It's even more realistic than Car Mechanic Simulator 2014. There's no hand-holding, but that said... it's FUN! Yes, you may have to do a Google search for a part here or there on your first few jobs, but it's an excellent learning tool to develop a basic understanding of critical car components.

The controls are incredibly intelligent and easy, and the ability to buy upgrades every 1,000xp is an excellent addition.

I really hope they do a Car Mechanic Simulator 2016, and I hope they go even deeper than before.

This is one of the most rewarding games I have ever played.

reviewText:
Thanks For This Game

This is the first game I ever wished my dad was still around to sit down with me to see. He was a total gear-nut, and his idea of a great evening (or morning, day, night, ha) was to take a coffee out into his garage and poke around his vehicles.

I never did aquire his love of mechanics, I instantly gravitated to the computers and electronics, being born in 1971.

This game may get me a little closer to working in my own garage, just like dad would have wanted to see. Even a little demystification goes a long ways.

So thanks!

reviewText:
Aside from a few minor crashes (which I'm sure will get sorted out), this game is an absolute blast!

Pros
Far more in depth then the 2014 version
Smoother performance
The price!
Free DLC
Excellent community feedback and involvment from the devs!
Cons
Some random crashes. (Again, I'm sure it'll get patched)
Some annoynances that'll amplify in the late game. Such as trying to memorize a rather large order list on the computer.
Very much a niche game.
Overall, this game is an easy buy for me. The price, the devs, and the quality speaks volumes to that. HOWEVER, I caution anyone thinking of buying this game to do your homework first! It is a point and click style. Very Niche. And nothing you learn from the game will help you fix your own car. But if you can get past that, then pick it up!

reviewText:
WOW - talk about exceeding expectations!

I was very reluctant to buy this game so close to it's release.... the screenshots and description sounded great, but I was quite honestly - half-expecting to be disappointed.  It was a pleasant surprise to discover that this game was not only bug-free (at least for me, during the 30ish hours of gameplay) - but also a LOT of fun!

The game is a very good high-level simulation.  It started off a bit slow, and there really wasn't much of a tutorial (at least not that I experienced) but the game is very intuitive.  I love the fact that you can upgrade your tools (although there is a limited number of options and once I maxed it, I wasn't sure what to do with the extra exp points).  The upgrades are actually useful (i.e. quicker assembly/disassembly of parts, increase chance to repair parts, diagnostic tools that tell you the condition" of parts in the car)  I also loved the fact that you can go to the auction house and buy cars which you can then fix up and either collect or choose to sell.  There is something very satisfying about buying an older beater covered in rust and dents and restoring it with shiny new parts.  You can also "test drive" your cars - which I also thought was neat.

TLDR - Great simulation game that smoothly delivers what it promises in the description (which is a rarity these days).
Seems to be bug free and has a very intuitive UI - although I found I had to "discover" most of the things myself since there didn't seem to be much of a tutorial.  This is a real time-sink and I've caught myself a few times now going to the auction house
date: buying an old beater and meaning to restore just a portion of it... but once you start and then see another rusting component that you just have to replace (and have gotten so quick and good at it)... it really does draw you into spending far more time than planned.... If being a mechanic was this much fun and satisfying (and no grease on my hands) then I could see being a mechanic ;-)\n\nDefinitely worth the price tag
recommended: and I hope that they intend to build upon this game (it seems to me like there are some areas in the game that were left intentionally empty - maybe for future expansions?)\n\nI'm happy with this purchase and will be keeping my eyes open for more games from these devs!"

reviewText:
From top to tail-pipe, Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is every bit a fun game, but it doesn't always live up to its predecessor (CMS 2014). Much has been improved in terms of added variety in cars, but there are still many areas that feel under-developed and lacking in substance, even in comparison to that earlier title.

That said, it's still a cracking ride, and an easy recommendation for anyone interested in cars and practical, mechanical puzzles. As long as you don't take the 'Simulator' part of the name too seriously, this is probably the closest you'll get to the sweaty, filthy joys of running your own chop shop.

Read my full review here: http://www.hookedgamers.com/pc/car_mechanic_simulator_2015/review/article-1468.html

reviewText:
This game DOES go on sale quite a bit, so definitely pick up while that's going on if you're thinking about getting it. For under $10, it's a decent buy. I definitely would not buy for $20 though.

At the same time that this game improves upon a lot of the downfalls of CMS 2014, it still lacks a way to stop the mind-numbing process involved in getting to the good content of the game.  After playing for two hours, I'm still grinding through basic jobs in hopes of eventually getting to actually work on my own cars.

I'd say the music has improved but still is an extremely repetitive playlist. They can't be more than 20 minutes long, if not less. **UPDATE** One new song was added since I wrote this. Probably a 25 minute playlist now. You're better off muting the game music and playing your own.

If you haven't played CMS 2014, then it will be more likely that you enjoy this game since you won't notice how little it has really changed. It has definitely gotten better since then, but I think that maybe some more time developing should have been used.

Basically, I really think that this game still needs work; but it looks like the developers are really looking for support from the community to do so gradually. That's fine. While it definitely is a finished product, some aspects of it just look very cheap. Don't get me wrong, I think this is a very good game. Not to mention it's pretty much the only mechanic sim out there right now. It's just that I feel like it still falls short of being a great game. It's almost feels like I bought an early access game without the label on it.

I don't want to say this about the game because I know that the developers have worked very hard for this, but I really wouldn't be able to pass off pretending to fix virtual cars as a fun activity to anyone.  You're really better off watching informational videos on YouTube on how to perform the tasks you'd be doing in the game and maybe practicing on a real car than playing this game. Although it may feel like it has some educational value, you don't really need more than basic car knowledge to get these jobs done. Let's be real.

I really don't agree with how little experience points you get from jobs that require you to diagnose several different systems and repair them. To even be able to access all of the new features of the game, you need to get a parking garage which costs 9000 XP. Over 20 jobs later, I'm only at 4000 XP. At least there's a bigger variety of problems to fix, unlike CMS 2014, but it's still just wayyyy too much. Why isn't the garage paid with money instead of experience anyway?

All this aside, the game gets good support and still has updates and DLC coming, so there's hope all of this gets fixed eventually.

reviewText: This game is pretty good. I got it with all of the DLCs up to this point on sale and it was well worth it. Even though it is a simulator" it is limited in what it simulates. It does let you take in repair jobs and remove old parts to replace them with newer ones. You have to put the cars on the lift to be able to access certain areas of the car; other parts of the car are only accessible under the hood. You have to remove certain parts first in order to get to other parts. You have to order replacement parts for the repair jobs you do. What the game does not simulate are things like the following: best practices
date: like disconnecting the battery before doing jobs like removing the starter and such. You don't have to torque done wheel lugs in a start pattern. You can't bulk order parts like spark plugs and oil filters that you are going to regularly need in order to get better pricing. As a matter of fact
recommended: you cannot even shop around from multiple suppliers to get better deals on parts. Another example is that you have an oil pan to catch oil when you drain the oil sump. However
voteText: it is solely for role play purposes; you don't get a huge mess on the floor if you drain the oil with nothing to catch it. Also
helpfulPercent: you can remove the drain pan under the engine without first draining all the oil out.\n\nThink of this game as more of a 3-D puzzle game. You will learn the basics of what car parts are
votesHelpful: where they are on the vehicle and how they fit with other parts. You won't really learn any real auto mechanics
votesTotal: though.\n\nI have really enjoyed this game
votesFunny: because there is always some new goal to work toward. As you get more experience and money
commentsCount: you can upgrade your tools and also your shop to make diagnosis and repairs easier and faster. Eventually you can buy your own car at auction and then "soup it up" but I haven't gotten to that point yet.\n\nThis game looks good and the controls make sense
column16: though there are some little annoyances like having to always use the ESC key to close windows instead of the key that you used to open the window. The music is terrible but you can turn it off.\n\nThis is a good one if you like cars and want to pretend like you have your own shop. No bruised knuckles or greasy hands either!"

reviewText:
The game is nice, enjoyable, fun and I really like the level of details being just right without being way too much nor not touching base. The fewer screws from the last version is surely welcome as is the much better graphics. The bad however vastly outnumber the good about this game.

The absolute worst thing is the repetition. I bought the game for the promise of buying broken cars, fixing them and selling them back but guess what, that requires 9000 EXP and 50,000 USD to unlock. EXP is gathered snail-slow, 100 per fixed car and 1 for installing or uninstalling an item. That's 10+ hours for me and I'm still on 6,500 EXP doing the exact same thing on each car over and over again. In a way I guess the developers knew there isn't much variety in the game itself so the flooded it in a way that it needs forever to get you anywhere.
I have a decent computer and still the game takes 15-20 seconds to load a car! I'm not talking startup time, each time you take a job, that's the waiting time before the car appears in my garage. Taking the car for a test drive, same wait. It's really frustrating.
Taking off the wheels is driving me crazy. I am aware that most car fixes need the wheels removed but the game takes it to a crazy level. If there are 4 steering/suspension problems in a car, rest assured each is on a different wheel. Same thing for timing belts and things that require a lot of unscrewing to reach. 2 pistons on a V engine? Almost certainly on different engine-body parts. Again I think this is intentional to make the game play longer for lack of original content.
Overall the game is good, I welcome the mechanical simulation part, quite nice but the game content itself is very short if the repetition is at least limited and the game should be priced according to this criteria, the current price is a highway robbery for the actual content.

reviewText:
Some major points.

I can say for certain the core gameplay is pretty decent. Informative for someone like me who only knows a few part names and has made few repairs on their car. There are a number of additions that i feel should defintely be included though. More fluids, electronics repair, part descriptions, better damage indicators rather than generic rust, and just listening to engine sounds to diagnose problems quicker - to name a few.

This isnt a simulator, rather a collection of minigames based on the reality of auto mechanics.


The progression and experience earning rate is dreadfully slow, though. It does feel like hours before i got to my first 1000 Xp and chose my first measly upgrade.


Load times are pretty merciless. I really wish they would focus on smoothing it out rather than other features.


Most importantly though; the DLC. Why on Earth would you release a Gold"/complete version of this game that collects all of the downloadable content if you're gonna release another new dlc pack after
date: separately?? That's total lack of respect for your customers. I cant see why they wouldnt include it in an update
recommended:
at least for those have the Gold version like me.


This is an ethics issue that i cant forgive them for. I can praise the simple repair aspect of the game but i wouldnt recommend this on a account of poor professionalism from the developer."

reviewText:
I don't think I've played one of these games before, so I jumped into this one with intrepidation.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o13cAl9RpoE

The game boasts new cars, new tools, new options, and more parts. Create and expand your auto repairs service empire. Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 will take you behind the scenes of daily routine in car workshop. Take on the role of the car mechanic and repair cars for your clients. Spend the earned money on expanding your workshop and improving your skills. Buy worn out cars, renovate them and sell with profit or become a famous car collector. If you manage your business well, you will surely succeed in the market.   - Recommended!

reviewText:
Ahh, another year, another CMS

I was looking foward for this (CMS 2k15). In all honesty, the game blew me away.

Not only modern day shitboxes are on the game, but classic muscle cars are on here, which is right up my alley. They also grew a pair of balls by adding a V8 and making an L4 with and without DOHC (Dual Over-Head Cam). The only, and I mean ONLY bad thing about this game is the XP system. Final gameplay rating, 9/10.

I also gave a brief description on realism of the parts on CMS2k14, so might as well make one here amiorite?

Anywho, this game blew CMS'14 out of the water. They moved the oil filter to the bottom, which is what I stated. Not only that, but they added more parts to work on, including ABS, even MORE rubber bushings, sterring rack, and much, much more. I'd rate the realism 10/10.

Final rating: 9.5/10. I highly suggest getting this for people into cars, or just want to learn some basics, like oil changes, brakes, etc.

reviewText: This felt more like a demo than a full-fledged game. People bring their cars in and tell you what seems to be wrong. You unscrew an endless series of bolts, find the faulty part, order a replacement, then put everything back together. The game uses color cues to tell you which part is faulty, and guides you as your reconstruct the relevant part of the vehicle, so there is very little challenge. It got old after about an hour.\n\n3/10

Let me start by saying.... I know nothing about fixing cars !!

Please dont let the fact you know nothing of fixing a car put you off this game folks!!

It is a very good game, and you should buy it, support its development further, there are things i would love too see added, a few things i would prefer to have a option to disable/enable and so forth. but thus far enjoying it...

reviewText:
Slow, progress is painfully slow, so slow it's like having a dead end boring job in real life, Except you don't get paid, so... total waste of time.
The game is fun, initially.
It's fun when I fix the first car, it's fun when I fix the first complex part. But, you'll need to fix the same boring simple car, screw and unscrew the same spot thousands of times, BEFORE you can even get to play with the second car.

Just speed up the experience and money! or just open up all the cars!

Seriously, why?
Game developers don't get paid extra for holding gamers playing longer (by wasting time).
It's a single player game, and a car mechanic game, there's literally nothing to brag about for spending(wasting) so much time on it.
It's the desert bus game with a better interface. Playing it should be considered performance art.

reviewText:
I'm going to try my best to convince you to not waste $20.

The game is far from being finished, and the small amount of work and dedication that the developers put in tells me it never will be finished. RDG seems incapable of adding the smallest features, one fine example being keybinding they swore to add over a year ago. Also, when confronted about their lack of work, they get defensive (one instance even instantly locking the complaint thread). The only times they actually respond to any forum threads is a little before and a little after an update. Now, the only content they can add are vehicles, and more and more vehicles. I have yet to see even one feature added that they have promised on their suggested features" thread.

Altogether
date: I highly advise you don't buy this game."

reviewText:
You basically take apart cars and replace broken parts (which are shown as covered in rust). As you gain experiemce you will unlock ability to repair parts rather than replace them with new ones. Also you gain access to some diagnostic tools which willl tell you what is broken, but you will rarely use them because they'll just color code what you already see as rusty as thus broken.

First 10 hours of the game you are likely to have lots of fun, but soon after you will inadvertly realize you have just been taking apart 3 variants of engines and 3 variations of undercarriages stuffed in different chasis all that time.

There is little progression to speak of. In fact the only difference awaiting you at the end is option to buy  broken cars and sell them after you have fixed them the same way as completing the repair job.

There's no customization, no tuning and virtually no driving cars in this game. If you're looking for that you will be dissapointed.

If you're looking for simplistic puzzler to kill 10-15 hours in you will enjoy this title. If you're looking for something akin to classic games like street rod, you will find this title dull and repetitive.

reviewText: Like everyone, I'm impressed with the level of detail of when dismantling the car, but the game itself..boring to anyone except someone who does this for a living.  It is a GAME so it's missing things that make it a true simulator. No angry customers or budget for keeping the place running. Customers coming back to say you didn't put a screw or a bolt back...accidents there in the garage..challenges, maybe you get to go to Nascar and have to SPEED repair cars.  There needs to be a clock period. Where you quote a customer a time to pick up so you have to work a little faster. And for the love of god please allow us to add our own music..itunes play list..something.\nHearing the sound of the wratchet (may have spelled that wrong) definitely did take me back to being a little girl in the garage with my Papa but as a hard core simulator fan this falls short.\nIt plays more like a mechanic class than an actual game.  I'll give it a good review just because you did an amazing job on the parts.  But I won't be buying any more of your games ladies and gents. You need to take a look at other simulators and add a LOT MORE to make it a true Sim.

reviewText:
These games are difficult to recommend.  If you know cars well you will be insulted by how much they leave out, and if you don't know cars but want to learn more you'll be grosly misled.   I enjoyed 2014 more than 2015.  Because 2015 didn't fix any of my complaints from the first game, it would be very awkward to recommend it.  However, it is not a bad game.

ProsImproved Graphics.
More detail on car parts and repairs.
You can now buy your cars from auctions.
ConsNo campaign mode.
Work orders are less creative because there is no campaign.  2014 would tell you the car makes clank sounds and accelerates slowly" and then you had to figure out what was broken.  2015 just gives you large lists of broken parts to fix.  Not nearly as interesting.
2014 would also have you plug the code reader into the obd port.  2015 has you use the code reader on the actual parts
date:
very odd.
You still don't have to add transmission fluid after putting the transmission back in place.  Same goes for anti-freeze in the radiator.
Its still fairly difficult to line-up the oil-catch under the oil plug.
Some of the jobs are still absurd expensive
hoursPlayed: 000 on crappy econoboxes to fix them.  Some of the parts are still crazy priced.\nThe interface and controls are still awkward and counter-intuitive.\nSome tasks
voteText: such as removing the wheels
helpfulPercent: still take far too long.\nOk
votesHelpful: so the list of cons is big.  Do I recommend the game?  I would recommend 2014 before this game.  It seems like 2015 didn't solve any of major issues with the series and they took some of the core expierence away by getting rid of campaign mode.\n"

reviewText:
Always start with a Joke

A penguin is driving along the motorway eating a tub of Ben and Jerrys Phish food ice-cream and making a hellova mess when suddenly the car lurches to a stop with steam coming out of the bonnet.

The penguin covered in ice-cream phones for a breakdown truck which arrives promptly and the mechanic is not phased to see he’s been called out by a talking penguin and gets to work under the bonnet.

After a couple minutes the mechanic closes the hood and looks at the rather stained penguin and says “you look like you have blown a seal” and the penguin say “ah no, its Ice-cream”

Now that the ice is broken, lets get down to business.

Good concept, spoiled by a constant stream of below average DLCs that add little other than new new car shapes.

Like all of these simulators, the business side of the game is pointless and only there to slow your collecting down.

Despite 70hours of play, I'd only reccommend this on Sale and to sombody with OCD.

More than a year on and the developers promised steam achievements are nowhere to be seen

reviewText: Very much a niche sim that requires you to have a lot of knowledge about the subject matter already. There is no real tutorial, help file or wiki to help you find what parts are to be found where. Combined with the ho-hum camera, this means you'll spend most of your time clicking around the car, hoping to hit the hot spot with the correct name. If you're out of luck, it'll be hidden inside other components. Strangely, finding the right parts to replace seems to be the core game component. The other mechanics are bolting/unbolting said parts and ordering replacements online. Oh, and you get to push the button on the lift.\n\nThe music is very much an acquired taste, so bring your own MP3s. Grab a Haynes manual and a lot of patience while you're at it.

reviewText:
If you played CMS2014 and enjoyed the basic premise, you'll enjoy CMS2015.  CMS2014 was basically a series of puzzles where you're given a car and have to find the broken parts and replace them, but Endless mode left you wanting more because all it did was throw broken cars with no explanation of what might be wrong at you and make you tear your hair out trying to find that one busted rubber bushing.

CMS2015 fixes that.  The entire game is like Endless mode from CMS2014, but now there are dynamically generated jobs that have basic problem descriptions (Car is loud, handles funny, engine keep cutting out, etc) to help limit how much of the car you have to tear apart to find the problem.  2015 also adds basic bodywork and the ability to paint cars (you have to unlock this part of your garage).

The most fun (and profit) in my opinion, comes later.  You can, after you add a parking garage to your shop, go to auto auctions and bid on junkers, then restore them and sell them for profit.  The more you fix up, the more money the car is worth when you sell it.

Compared to CMS2014, the cars have many, many more parts.  You can unlock some new diagnostic tools (compression gauge and voltmeter) and some old ones make a return (diagnostic path and road test, which is much improved).

They're doing a wonderful job listening to their playerbase as they move forward with future updates (they've added some features and fixed some bugs at the request of the community already, the game has only been out a few weeks and they've released over half a dozen patches), and they're planning on adding more.  Chiptuning hasn't returned yet, but they're looking for good tuning ideas to implement instead of 2014's three-bar system, and they're taking votes on which cars to put into the first paid DLC pack.  They've released two free cars already.

CMS2015 does everything CMS2014 did right, and fixes just about everything CMS2014 did wrong.  If you had fun playing 2014, or you enjoy knowing How Stuff Works, you really can't go wrong with this.

It's not AAA GOTY, but it's a wonderful casual game.

I brought this last year and was how can I say underwhelmed by the game.

reviewText:
Fun game. Being a mechanic its not the most technically correct but does a pretty good job of having the correctly named parts. Its repetitive at first but once you get enough cash you can buy cars at auction and do a restore. That being said though its just more of the same as you have to then take off every part, repair it if possible then put them all back on.

Fun game if you like car mechanics. They are also working on improvements and DLC addons that should bring lot more to the game like tuning etc. Right now its a parts changing game.

The actual game play is not like the trailer videos. You never see third person and body work is just clicking the part off, buying a new one then clicking it back on again. Painting is 3 sliders then a click to paint.

The test track is great fun where you can burn rubber and generally drive like a hooligan.

I may sound a bit negative but I really like the game and would recommend it as its only going to get better

reviewText:
I had no knowledge about car parts or any mechanic stuff, i bought this because simply i love cars. And oh boy i got hooked. And here's why i love this game so much:

Story:
You're a car mechanic and you fix'em cars.

Presentation:
This game didn't really go for photorealism despite being a simulator, and some parts look really funky at times, but most of the time it doesn't really matter because this game runs really smooth and you don't need a beast to run this very smoothly so good optimaztion there. And mostly i didn't really cared about funky looking parts because i had so much fun. Oh, i almost forgot to talk about how much detail and effort has put into this game. You will be surpised to see how detailed the car parts are even thorugh they didn't went for the photorealism.

Gameplay:
Gameplay in this game is so addicting and fun for both car lovers and problem solvers, so in the first few jobs the game tells you what to fix, but 3-4h in the game gives less infomation about the problem and you need to dig(or shall i say, screw) your way into the car to find the problem and replace it with new parts. Also this game really teaches you about car parts and how to remove them and put'em back in. It is a very fun and addicting IF you're a car lover like me or a problem solver, novice mechanic, or people who like puzzle games. Well if you're not one of those people i suggest stay away from this game because it's not for you.

Overall:
Overall this game is perfect for Car lovers, problem solvers, novice mechanic, and people who like puzzle games. For those people this game gets 9/10 BUY THIS GAME NOW. But if you're not one of those people do not purchase this game. I myself would put a recommended review because this game deserves more positive reviews.

reviewText: GREAT GAMES. EXCELLENT

reviewText:
There are quite a lot of pros and only a few cons to the game. Mind you, I will be comparing the older version to the newer version.

Pros:
-It is not very laggy: The biggest issue I had with the older version was that I set my game to the lowest video settings, but I still kept on lagging. This game takes that and throws it in the bin. With the same computer and same specs, the 2015 version was much more smoother than the 2014 version. I had at least 30fps all the way, whereas I would have 15-20fps on the 2014 version.
-Interesting Campaign Mode: The one in CMS2014 was very controlled, you were given the same puzzle as everyone else who played the game. This gives you the choice to select the orders you want to take, and that is a game changer. No longer do you HAVE to do an order. You get to pick what you want to do. i.e I don't feel like fixing that guy's brakes, so I'll just select the order with the engine problems instead. This helps to make the game much more smoother and much more playable.
-Much fewer glitches: I had a problem with CMS2014, and that was my order #43 glitched and I couldn't finish the order no matter how closely I followed the instructions. Since this is a newer game, we don't have as many glitches anymore. This game is being constantly updated, so it allows for improvement all the time.
-Cool DLCs: We have had two DLCs come out by the time I am writing this review, Visual Tuning and Young Timer. Young Timer is free, with the nice little Fiat 500 lookalike. The Visual Tuning DLC does cost some money, however it is much more cheaper compared to the price tags on the other DLCs.

Cons:
-Time Consuming: Unless you are an absolute car bore who likes fixing the cars in this game like I do, you are not going to have a fun time. This is a simulator of what mechanics do on a daily basis, so ofcourse it is going to be time consuming, what did you expect?
-Unlockables: In CMS2014, we had the OBD scanner as a tool since the beginning of the game. Why do we need to work on 10 cars maximum in order to unlock the tool that we had for a long time in the previous game? They could've let some tools remain like they were in the previous game. However, it does add for an interesting aspect to the gameplay, because now you get to work for the things you really want. Although that is interesting to me, it might not be to the other gamers.
-Repair Uncertainty: Now again, unless you are a car enthusiast that finds these innovations interesting to the gameplay, you are probably not going to like the fact that there is a chance that the item you repair may not be fixed successfully.

Overall, I think they did an excellent job with the new 2015 simulator. The new additional features are absolutely worth every single penny of that price tag. This new game completely demolishes the other older one, and I am not saying this because my CMS2014 Order #43 did not work. I genuinely believe this new game is a huge step forward from the previous one. I can now only imagine how much greater the 2016 version will be, definitely a rival to the upcoming Street Tuning Revolution. I am only joking, that game is a total in depth tuning game and it will take Red Dot Games a little while to catch up to that level, eventhough in my opinion it is very close. Then again, I have not played Street Tuning Evolution yet, so I can't tell the gap there might exist between the two games. CMS2016, that is a game definitely to look forward to.

reviewText: In many ways this is a leaps and bounds improvement over the 2014 version, however one thing I think it's missing is some sort of achievement or goal.  You play, fixing cars, solving problems, even going as far as buying wrecks and restoring them... but by the time I got there, I kinda of wondered what the point was.  At least the previous version started you small and you could upgrade to bigger and better shops as it progressed... this one, you get 1 shop and the cost of upgrading it and XP requirements are almost too easy.  Still, it's inexpensive and a good time sink... but don't be surprised if you reach a point where 'what now?' has you moving on to a different game.

reviewText:
So. Car Mechanic Simulator 2015. The year is almost over, and I have a good 100 hours on this game, so it's about time for a review.
What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? It's definitely a very good game, it's informative in its own way, educational, and just plain fun, especially when you save up enough money and experience to expand your garage, get the paint shop, get the underground parking, and go to the auction house to buy wrecks you can fix up and sell for a profit.
Of course, things are simplified a lot under the hood of each car you get to work on. I'm no mechanic, but I know enough of cars to have done maintenance on my own cars, and I have studied a lot of stuff for stories I write in which a character is an actual mechanic. There is in fact a funny thing about that; the game showed me painfully well how I got most of my knowledge about cars. It started in Dutch, as that is the language set on my laptop, and one of the first customer cars I got in showed a list that said there was a part that needed replacing. And I was all like; what the hell is that? So I saved and quit to menu, set the game language to English, started back up again, looked at the list, and went; Ohhh! Duh, a rubber bushing! Why didn't you just SAY so? I KNOW those! (And I know the name of that part mainly from watching YouTube videos of HotRod Magazine/HotRod Garage, and reading those kind of magazines - in English. For about 70% of the parts, I have NO clue what they are by the Dutch names alone)

How simplified is it under the hood? Well, all cars have similar parts, for one. A front suspension has a crossmember, shocks, springs, a swaybar and end links, steering rack with inner and outer tie rods, upper and/or lower control arms, wheel knuckle housing, wheel hub, brake disk, pads, and a brake caliper. All but one or two cars come with a brake servo, and the newer models with an ABS pump and control unit. Brake lines? Nope. Brake fluid? Nope. A need to bleed the system after you rebuilt it? Nope.
The engines? Let's stick with my favorite type of cars; the old ones. There's several classics that are all too recognizable; a 1957 Chevy Bel Air, a 1969 Ford Mustang, a 1968 Chevrolet Chevelle, a 1969 Dodge Charger. Of course they are not called that; the game has given each car its own brand and type. Big plus; they have actually taken the time to design logos and name badges that are on the cars, and they look good, too!
But, the engines. Those four cars I mentioned all come with a carburated overhead-cam V8 engine. All parts are interchangeable, except for the two-carb intake manifold that comes on the Mustang. Have you bought a Chevelle and want to spruce it up a bit with a dual carburetor setup? Sorry, no can do, that dual-carb intake manifold is not an optional part for that car. Even when you take the V8 out of a Mustang and put it in the Chevelle, you can only put on the single-carb intake manifold. The only optional parts you can change on a car are the rims, and body parts if you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack.
For the rest, though, it's good. Quite simplified, but with plenty of detail parts even so. Take apart one of those old V8's, and you find yourself with a box full of individual rocker arms and pushrods which you can take out one by one - and there's sixteen of them in one engine.

There's one big drawback, though. You can't take the whole engine plus transmission out of the car in one big lump and put it on an engine stand to disassemble it, like almost any car restorer does; you have to disassemble, and reassemble it, in the car. And some parts you can only reach from underneath. Once you have gotten down to the engine block, it's; take out pistons, lift car, get under, remove oil pan (if you already hadn't), remove crankshaft caps, remove crankshaft, get out, lower car, remove engine block. Fix up or buy new one. Put in engine block, lift car, get under, put in crankshaft, put in crankshaft caps, get out, lower car, put in pistons, lift car, get under, put on oil pan and filter, get out, lower car, rebuild rest of the engine. That would be SO much easier if you could just take the whole thing out, put it on an engine stand, and disassemble/reassemble there.

And the simplification shows. The plug wires are the only wires you'll find in the whole car. The detailing goes as far as to put individual clips on the air filter box/distributor cap you have to take off, but a wiring loom for all the electrics? Not there. Gaskets? Not there. There's a fuel filter, but fuel lines? Nope. Brake lines? Nope. And even on the most hashed-out rusty wreck of a 1957 Bel Air you buy at the auction house, ALL the bolts are always brand new. The rims and parts of the suspension/engine may be so rusted they are beyond repair, but they still come off with three turns of your wrench on the brand new bolts holding everything in place.

The same goes for the fixing of the parts. You have a work table where you can fix a good number of the parts you take off a car. Butthe fixing process is; click. You managed to repair the part! Condition is now X%! Or; click. You failed to repair the part. Condition has decreased. (and it always decreases to a point so low you can't re-attempt to fix it again. So if you hash up a part, it's utterly broken and you need to buy a new one)

Still, overall, it's a great game. After 100 hours I'm still not bored of it, even if I'm doing pretty much the same things over and over again. It just has that certain something about it that keeps drawing you in to play it more. There's just a few little things that could make it even better.
- placing of the oil drain pan. That is SUCH a hit-and-miss, because you can't look upwards properly once you're moving that thing around. I end up just removing the oil pan and taking the $100 fine for oil cleanup, rather than to fiddle around with that drain and having it sit just a smidge too far to the left, right, front or back anyway.
- disassembling/reassembling the engine outside of the car on an angine stand. If that could be implemented, it would be SUCH an improvement.
- customizing of the cars. Currently, it's just visual with body parts and head/tail lights and bumpers, and rims, and only when you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack. If you were allowed to put different engines in different cars, or even do things like put that dual-carb intake on a single-carb V8 engine, that would make things a lot more fun. Also, speed parts would be nice. Take the tame little Pinto, yank out that four-banger engine, plop in a V8 with a high-lift cam, dual or triple carburetors and a turbo or a blower, and you suddenly have a much more interesting car.
- graphics. Not the overall game graphics; those are pretty good as is. But some extra graphics for the cars? That would be a lot more fun. Take the Dodge Charger, give it a new paint job, and let us put on a bumblebee stripe around the rear end, for instance. Or racing stripes over the hood and trunk of the Chevelle. Or a spiffy flame-job. Hell yeah.
- the test drive. Currently, there are in fact different engine sounds for the different cars, and some different driving characteristics. But the handling is atrocious, and the whole thing feels a bit... tacked on. Almost like it was an afterthought. There is massive potential for improvement there.
- bodywork on the cars. At the moment, it's front bumper, headlights, hood, front fenders, doors, trunk lid, taillights, rear bumper. Not even windshields/rear windows/side windows (and everyone who ever restored an old car knows that the quarter panels/rear fenders and floor pans are 90% of the time the areas that need the most work). I can see a lot of potential for improvement there as well, the outer bodywork, and the interior as well. Allow us to put in leather bucket seats, for instance, or give the interior a different color than black.

Do I recommend this game though? Hell yes!

reviewText: I do like this game, and I am a retired auto repair shop owner.  I bought it in alpha and enjoyed it and played it a lot early on.  But after a while the challenge diminishes rapidly.  It only takes a few times to learn a car, and new cars are not much of a challenge.  The DLC of new vehicles are expensive and there should be many more vehicles in the base game.  The vehicles are typically based on a basic format so if you have 4WD DLC your just getting one basic vehicle with some minor changes between them.  They represent different companies but are all designed the same.  The only really different vehicle is the Maluch, and its, just weird.  All in all I played over 120 hours.  You have to have the visual tuning DLC to make the game playable, but they charge seperately for it, so you know what your in for with this game.

reviewText:
If you don't know what the pointy thing is at the midsection of your arm when you bend it or the soft squishy cushion like area at the top of your legs.. and you sometimes get them confused - you can still play this game.

If you like to be led through all games regardless of genre and large open spaces cause you to reach for that old paper bag - you can still play this game.

If you're looking for something a bit different after you've upgraded your weapons for the 'Nth' time and now you don't remember what it is or you're stuck on deciding whether your character's hair should flop to the right or left then give this game a shot.

You learn real stuff about cars, instead of panicking and fleeing to the nearest dark corner when I lift the bonnet of my trusty Cruiser I can now point at a lot of the parts and name them. You can spend real time fixing up cars and then sell them on to earn money to buy more cars to sell or add to your personal collection.

Also the devs regularly update this simulator, they take an active role in the community and cues from the suggestions made on how to improve the game.

More fun than a dog with a box, dogs love boxes why is this?!

reviewText:
Game is very intuitive and for someone like me who knows very little about car parts it can teach you quite a bit. It also eases you into the game slowly, giving you easy things to do at the start then getting more complicated as you gain experience. Just be careful you use ALL the tools at your disposal, unlike what I did below.

Had a job where one of the problems was a lack of power.

Used the test track and test path, no luck finding the problem.

Took absolutely everything out of the engine bay, couldn't find the problem either.

Remembered I had an electronic meter I earned earlier in the game which I could use. The problem was the fuel pump in the fuel tank at the back of the car.

Smacked myself in the head, replaced the fuel pump and had to put the whole engine back together.

10/10 would do it again.

reviewText:
When I started to play this game, I had just about no car knowledge whatsoever. But I figured that as I own one, this could be a good opportunity to actually see how it works. And CMS was a great tool for that. Here's my pros and cons list:

Pros:
-Excellent learning curve.
-Easy controls
-Interesting lineup of cars to work on
-Super relaxing game
-Constant updating makes the game better and better

Cons:
-A bit redundant eventually. (I got every upgrade and reached about a millions dollars now with no idea on what to spend it all)
-No preview option when using the paint shop.
-No real city to ride your own cars once you get them

To conclude, CMS 2015 is well-made, fun game. Learning how cars work is really nice playing this game. You WILL enjoy it even if you have no prior knowledge on cars. Devs update it often to keep it interesting and release awesome DLCs as well. I would definitely recommend this game!

reviewText:
I've played about a hundred hours on this game.  I've never been one to RACE thru a game at a RECORD pace, and this one was no exception.  It took me about 90 hours to get to the point where I had all the tools and upgrades, and could afford the parking lot, the final purchase required to buy cars at auction (the only way to OWN your own cars).

I haven't read thru the community forums much.  In the beginning, I needed to go to YouTube to find videos on how to find the parts in some of the cars, such as the fuel pump (located on top of the fuel tank, btw ...), and it took me awhile to figure out how the color scheme works with each mode, as they change depending on whether you're in DISASSEMBLE mode, ASSEMBLE or a third mode you can use to diagnose the condition of the parts.

Once you get it, it's a piece of cake to figure out the order of taking the car apart and putting it back together.

I also bought the DLC, but I haven't seen much in the way of custom parts yet, other than RIMS and PAINT.  In fact, that brings me to my WANTS, or things that would make this game better.

1.  Why not be able to take the cars out and drive them around a city or RACE TRACK?  The one little test course is a quick set of bumps and turns thru an alley, and gets old really quick.

2.  The addition of tracks or courses would make improving your car more exciting, and maybe motivate you to build it with 100% new condition parts.  As it is, you really need to have a junker to tell any difference in performance from car to car.  Beefing up the UPGRADE system would be nice, too.  Souping up the motor and suspension, or TURBO and NITROUS kits would make shaving times off a time trial a lot of fun, and give you some reason to stay with the game after you get to where I am, where everything gets a little tedious.

3.  For me it's hard to understand why you can repair CERTAIN partz at certain times, but not others.  You end up with hundreds of broken partz that you have to sell one by one, mouse CLICK and ENTER.  When selling stuff, the sound of my keyboard and mouse is like an old manual typewriter.  You can sell the JUNK" with one button
date: but anything above 10% condition gets thru that filter.  And its all junk if you can't repair it
recommended: unless you want to build cars out of damaged partz.\n\n4.  What about a reputation system?  The cheaper
voteText: and faster you repair carz should bring you more trusting and higher paying customers.  As it is

votesHelpful: by clicking on a phone.  Rather sterile
votesTotal: and boring after a while.\n\n5.  Also
votesFunny: I don't know about the value of the cars.  There may be a list somewhere
commentsCount: but I haven't seen it.  Makes auctions a little silly if you can't tell the sale value of the car before bidding.\n\n6.  How about some RACING WHEEL support
column16: along with the tracks or city driving?  These muscle cars BEG to be driven hard
column17: not just crashed and trashed in an alley with KEYBOARD controls.  It would be fun to drive thru downtown traffic

reviewText:
Car Mechanic 2015 is a definite improvement from the 2014 version. There is a lot more detail in the work you do to the cars. I find myself not wanting to stop playing. I finish one job and I tell myself this is the last one I'm going to do today, then I start looking at the next job and find myself working on it till I finish. It is very addictive!
If you know nothing about cars, Car Mechanic 2015 will help you understand the basics of what is what on a car an where it can be found!
I can't get enough of this game! I have had no issues with the game play at all! If you don't have it yet, get it, you'll love it!

Since I am a trained mechanic myself there are a few things that should be added to the next version, if there is going to be next version, like powers tools! Instead of using the ratchet sounds add in some power tool sound fx! Like the impact wrench and an air wratchet! These would make the game even more enjoyable!
Also custom paint jobs woud be really cool as well! Something where you could have a set of custom designs the customer would like to put on their car and paint it in the paint booth! Even metallic colors would look great! Something for the designers to think about! I have a lot of ideas for future Car Mechanic Simulators!

This game is well worth the money! Two thumbs up from me! Definitly on the top of my gaming list!

reviewText: In many ways this is a leaps and bounds improvement over the 2014 version, however one thing I think it's missing is some sort of achievement or goal.  You play, fixing cars, solving problems, even going as far as buying wrecks and restoring them... but by the time I got there, I kinda of wondered what the point was.  At least the previous version started you small and you could upgrade to bigger and better shops as it progressed... this one, you get 1 shop and the cost of upgrading it and XP requirements are almost too easy. reviewText:
I have kicked out considebilly more hours on this game compered to Car mechanic Simulator 2014.
I found this one far more enjoyable where im feeling i was achieving something, like to better my skills better my garage and to buy rusty old knackared cars, Strip them apart repair what i can and put it all back together with 100% confition parts so it was like new.
Dont get me wrong there is pleanty of areas for improvements but by far an enjoyable Simulator especially if your into cars and like myself do all my car repair work at home myself.

Pros:
Nice selection of cars diffrencing from little 4 Cylinder OHV engines to big V8 Quad cam engines
Customisation of the body i.e. put sportier bumpers on etc and diffrent wheels
Ability to paint and do through checks before putting car on ramp to fix
Everything can be dissasembled so all you can be left with is the shell and interior

Cons
Lacking some vital parts of the engine like ECU and sensors i.e. MAF sensor Cam sensor etc would make for more realism
Ability to start the engine when rebuilt on the ramp, Nothing better than rebuilding an engine and turning the key to hear it fire for the first time
Have to do correct cam and crank timing
Rebuild cylinder heads by changing valves and stem seals and springs etc
Be able to do engine conversions put a bigger engine in a smaller engined car
A rolling road to test the power output of the car see where it is losing power or where your gaining

These are a few of the Pro's and cons i can think of right now i know there is more cons as i know where i would like to see improvement done, My biggest con to this game is Loading times, My PC is not big Spec i run a Core 2 Quad Q6600 with 4GB Ram and a Saphire HD 7970 Titan X 3GB Graphics card and game is installed on a Western Digital Black 1TB hard drive and the loading between road tests and going back to garage can be as ong as over a Minute which is really Frustrating, Maybe a diffrent case in installed on a SSD but very frustrating to have these load Times.

All in all i Would Highley recomend this game as i have had Fair few hours of enjoyment from this and will continue to have More
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Pros:

+Nice car selection
+XP based game play to unlock parts of the shop is a majot plus
+With the current platform it is a great base for a lot of things. i.e when exiting the garage the map screen. plenty of room for say addon tracks and things to that nature.
+Graphics
+/-Depth of engine and car deconstruction
+Parking garage is a amazing idea (got about 4 project cars stored in there lol)

Cons:

-Rusted parts. They are a dead give away. Granted rust does happen, just wish there was a difficulty setting to change this for more experienced players.
-/+Depth of deconstruction. It does go into a lot of detail, but I miss things like the hoses from the air box to the intake. Would be nice to see radiator hoses, maybe even brake lines and fuel lines.
-Variety. Seems like every car I work on I'm doing the same things to the same engine, chasis, etc, except the body of the car looks different.
-Limited customization. I know the dev plans on releasing DLC but I can't wait lol. I would love to buy a beat up car from the auction and a massive tiwn turbo with a racing suspention. Turn around and, for example turn a 30k car into a 100k car.


My biggest hope is for user created addons. Its a lot of work for the devs to keep up on the game adding new content all the time. There are people out there that can some pretty spectacular things with modding programs.

All in all I love this game and give it a 10/10. I logged about 10 hours on my buddy's game when I went on vacation back home. As soon as I got back and walked into my house the first thing I did was buy this wonderful game.

reviewText: I do like this game, and I am a retired auto repair shop owner.  I bought it in alpha and enjoyed it and played it a lot early on.  But after a while the challenge diminishes rapidly.  It only takes a few times to learn a car, and new cars are not much of a challenge.  The DLC of new vehicles are expensive and there should be many more vehicles in the base game.  The vehicles are typically based on a basic format so if you have 4WD DLC your just getting one basic vehicle with some minor changes between them.  They represent different companies but are all designed the same.  The only really different vehicle is the Maluch, and its, just weird.  All in all I played over 120 hours.  You have to have the visual tuning DLC to make the game playable, but they charge seperately for it, so you know what your in for with this game.

Well. I'm hobbyist mechanic (meaning I worked on 3 of my cars) and the game is boring for me.

For that kind of beginners it should have wiki-style help or something, so they can learn stuff (Automation game has that - AWESOME game btw, I learned a lot about engines thanks to them)

Gameplay is very basic and repeatitive (is that a word? I'm not native speaker), after 2 hours, I calculated I have to repeat same stuff over and over for about 2 hours more to unlock new kind of repeatitive stuff to do..
So yeah, actually, in that matter it is a simulator, you get to do simple stuff over and over again :D

tl;dr - I didn't feel like car mechanic when playing this game. I felt like... I'm playing mediocre game. Other games let you feel your role better (again, check Automation, it's awasome)
