reviewText:
Gameplay: 7/10 It gets tedious. You'd better hope you like unscrewing things (and then attempting to repair them, failing, buying new things, and screwing them back on). Then again, I'm sure being an automotive mechanic gets boring after a while, too. The cars all have the same basic components, as most cars do, but some have different layouts for more specific systems, like rear brake drums instead of discs or I4/I6/V8/V8OHV engines, etc. Despite this variation, after a few cars, you've seen it all. There's a lot of attention to detail, but even then, the game is not 100% accurate. If it was, though, I'd imagine it would be a lot more difficut. I'm glad that driving does not happen much in this game, because the driving mechanics were honestly not very good at all. Besides that, everything runs smoothly without any serious glitches. It performs as advertised.

Graphics: 9/10 There isn't much to look at in this game, but what there is looks pretty nice. In other words, the textures and models all look great, but they mostly just sit there - no action.

Plot: 0/10 It's a game about being a mechanic. What were you expecting, an epic tale of love, loss, and man's journey to find himself? There's no plot, you just fix cars for hours. I'm not really factoring plot into the overall rating, because that isn't the point of the game as I see it.

Soundtrack: 4/10 One of this game's weakest points has to be the soundtrack. I know some mechanics, and I don't think many (if any at all) of them listen to EDM, and certainly not the same 5 songs in an endless loop. Now, you might think that it's fine. You'll just shut off the music and load up your own or whatever you usually do. Bad news:  YOU CAN'T SHUT IT OFF  (at least as far as I can tell). Now, it isn't  bad  EDM, it just gets super annoying. You must listen to the same songs over and over and over and over.

Replay Value: 4/10 This game quickly becomes boring. There are only so many variations on cars and so many different tasks you can perfect performing. After a while, there's just no point in playing. The Trader Pack added the ability to buy cars at auction and restore them to keep or sell, but the only thing you can do with the money from selling cars is buy more cars or more car parts. It's very circular. It just feels like there's something missing at the upper level of this game.

Overall: 60/100 I can't blame this game for being something I don't like. It's a simulation of being a mechanic, and I wasn't expecting much. So, as a game that simulates being an automotive repair specialist this game is probably a 90/100 (and stands pretty uncontested in its field). However, there's just about no replay value. There's no real reason to be satisfied with restoring even some of the nicest cars in the game because there's nothing to do with them after that, besides look at them and drive them around the generally pointless test track (the only textured driving course included with the game). The lack of replay value is what really ends up making this game kind of disappointing.  Suggestion:  What would make this game a 95/100 is a racing element: being able to buy performance-enhancing parts to upgrade your cars and then race for money. Despite its flaws, I'd say that Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is mostly worth the meager $19.99 it asks of your wallet.

reviewText: I've done engine/transmission swaps, factory and forged block and head rebuilds, and I'm currently in the process of attempting to make 800 rwhp on my '94 SC300 with a 2JZGTE VVTi/R154 swap.  Going with a GTX4088R, 2000cc Hi-Z Injector Dynamic injectors, dual 450 Walbro pumps, an OS Giken triple plate clutch with a hydraulic actuator conversion, Hypertune race intake manifold, a supra MK4 4.06 rear end, and many, many other mods.\n\nIn summary, I spend hours upon hours on forums reading about high HP builds and basic repair/maintenance on several different forum sites.  Even though my life is spent on cars outside of work, I can't get enough of this game because even with all of that experience, I still learn a thing or two each time that I play it.  Buy this game if you even have the slightest interest in automotive repair and modifications.

reviewText:
The first time I played this I burned through almost five hours of doing repairs. After a few days of playing it I'm starting to find it a little routine simply because I've gotten nearly all the experience perks that are available, and there's only 5 or 6 different models of vehicles that I've gotten to work on.

The best part of the game is the detective work, it makes the player think of where to look for problems and gives them tools to diagnose them. Early on you may be tempted to just rip apart the whole engine and put it all back in piece by piece (I've done it). That method works, but the game doesn't penalize you for the time it takes. Since the pieces are rudamentary an engine can be broken down to it's components inside of three RL minutes.

In the future I hope that the developers incorporate a timer to dole out experience or money based on how quickly you diagnosed and solved a problem. Ultimately I think I'll just get sick of looking at the same 60-70 parts and doing the same repairs over and over and lose interest, which is a shame because with some ingenuity and integration this could be a very long-lived and entertaining sim:

Motor bikes, company finances, hiring/firing AI staff to help on other cars, negotiating repair estimates, having something to do with the pile of junk you yank off cars, even a leveling and story mode are all things that could make me play this game a lot more frequently and for a longer time. Don't get me wrong, still very promising and even educational experience.

All in all, it's a great sim with a ton of potential and I'm really looking forward to seeing what direction it goes in. Reccomended, but sincerely hoping for more content to keep it interesting.

In the future I hope that the developers incorporate a timer to dole out experience or money based on how quickly you diagnosed and solved a problem. Ultimately I think I'll just get sick of looking at the same 60-70 parts and doing the same repairs over and over and lose interest, which is a shame because with some ingenuity and integration this could be a very long-lived and entertaining sim:

Motor bikes, company finances, hiring/firing AI staff to help on other cars, negotiating repair estimates, having something to do with the pile of junk you yank off cars, even a leveling and story mode are all things that could make me play this game a lot more frequently and for a longer time. Don't get me wrong, still very promising and even educational experience.

All in all, it's a great sim with a ton of potential and I'm really looking forward to seeing what direction it goes in. Reccomended, but sincerely hoping for more content to keep it interesting.

reviewText:
If you don't know what the pointy thing is at the midsection of your arm when you bend it or the soft squishy cushion like area at the top of your legs.. and you sometimes get them confused - you can still play this game.

If you like to be led through all games regardless of genre and large open spaces cause you to reach for that old paper bag - you can still play this game.

If you're looking for something a bit different after you've upgraded your weapons for the 'Nth' time and now you don't remember what it is or you're stuck on deciding whether your character's hair should flop to the right or left then give this game a shot.

You learn real stuff about cars, instead of panicking and fleeing to the nearest dark corner when I lift the bonnet of my trusty Cruiser I can now point at a lot of the parts and name them. You can spend real time fixing up cars and then sell them on to earn money to buy more cars to sell or add to your personal collection.

Also the devs regularly update this simulator, they take an active role in the community and cues from the suggestions made on how to improve the game.

More fun than a dog with a box, dogs love boxes why is this?!

reviewText:
I know how to work on cars and trucks. I was disappointed when I got into the game. There are only 4 engine types, one SUV and 1 truck. It is setup well but the order in which you remove parts is not like the real world. I understand why they made it this way but takes away from the real world aspect. I was hoping to see a different engine setup for each vehicle, was disappointed again. Once you learn how to do one engine they are all pretty much the same. Don't get me wrong for me it is still fun but would be better if there was more difference between the vehicles.

Brake jobs - Too easy
Suspension - Too easy
Engine Work - Needs more variety
Transmission - Too easy
Drivetrain - Too easy
Ignition System - Too easy
Fuel system - Too easy
Body Work - Too easy

All in all i would say it is too easy of a game for someone like me who has experience and a vast knowledge of how vehicles function & are built.

Just a word of advice... Do not think you can be a mechanic after playing this game. You will be pleasently disappointed.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A must have for a car nut! I love the game. I have worked on cars before and mostly everything is spot on - especially suspension wise. There are some parts that have either been omitted or overly simplified but - especially engine wise - but it's no big deal. It performs well but has a few weird quirks. I could not get the game to load until a user suggested I force-minimize the game via CTRL+ALT+DEL, then go back in, which oddly enough worked out.

PROS:
- Fun and educational
- Very accurate parts wise
- Great visuals
- Nice testing tools
- Good experience points and unlocks
- Nice soundtrack (in my opinion)

CONS:
- Odd performance quirks at times
- Long and frequent loading times
- Some overly simplified engine components
- Camera fights with you sometimes

SUGGESTIONS FOR CMS 2016:

- Let's get deeper into engine parts! I realize it might turn away some folks because engines can get very complex. Perhaps a difficulty setting where this is adjustable?

- Automatic transmissions. Every car in this game is a manual. Autos would be nice as they would introduce a whole new category of drivetrains.

- The aftermarket scene. I realize this is probably a can of worms, but a few performance mods wouldn't hurt. It's not uncommon for people to take their cars to shops and request performance parts. Throw in a dyno too!

reviewText:
I have kicked out considebilly more hours on this game compered to Car mechanic Simulator 2014.
I found this one far more enjoyable where im feeling i was achieving something, like to better my skills better my garage and to buy rusty old knackared cars, Strip them apart repair what i can and put it all back together with 100% confition parts so it was like new.
Dont get me wrong there is pleanty of areas for improvements but by far an enjoyable Simulator especially if your into cars and like myself do all my car repair work at home myself.

Pros:
Nice selection of cars diffrencing from little 4 Cylinder OHV engines to big V8 Quad cam engines
Customisation of the body i.e. put sportier bumpers on etc and diffrent wheels
Ability to paint and do through checks before putting car on ramp to fix
Everything can be dissasembled so all you can be left with is the shell and interior

Cons
Lacking some vital parts of the engine like ECU and sensors i.e. MAF sensor Cam sensor etc would make for more realism
Ability to start the engine when rebuilt on the ramp, Nothing better than rebuilding an engine and turning the key to hear it fire for the first time
Have to do correct cam and crank timing
Rebuild cylinder heads by changing valves and stem seals and springs etc
Be able to do engine conversions put a bigger engine in a smaller engined car
A rolling road to test the power output of the car see where it is losing power or where your gaining

These are a few of the Pro's and cons i can think of right now i know there is more cons as i know where i would like to see improvement done, My biggest con to this game is Loading times, My PC is not big Spec i run a Core 2 Quad Q6600 with 4GB Ram and a Saphire HD 7970 Titan X 3GB Graphics card and game is installed on a Western Digital Black 1TB hard drive and the loading between road tests and going back to garage can be as ong as over a Minute which is really Frustrating, Maybe a diffrent case in installed on a SSD but very frustrating to have these load Times.

All in all i Would Highley recomend this game as i have had Fair few hours of enjoyment from this and will continue to have More

reviewText: I think this is a really well put together game and it's actually interesting to play if you're a car person.\nI like working on my own project car and I learn as I go (IRL) and this certainly has helped me with some language, part names, and some basics of where things are and how they are connect.
